Fort Hays Kansas
January 22nd 1879
Assistant Adjutant General 
Dept of Mo. Fort Leavenworth Kas
Sir: I have the honor to report that in obedience to instructions conveyed in letter of 27th ult, I left Fort Hays [unclear] Dec 31st by rail for Fort Dodge in search of site for a cantonment for Six companies. Before starting I had determined upon a line of search, which I was subsequently forced by the extraordinary severity of the weather, and the depth of snow, to deviate from. I am however able to report a very thorough examination of the Country specially mentioned in the letter of December 27th.

     The North bank of the North Fork of Canadian is occupied by what may be termed a "Sand-Stream" which with a varying breadth of from one to

2
six miles follows the river from the immediate vicinity of Fort Supply to Fort Reno (probably further).
The river is very crooked, the "Sand-Stream" comparatively straight. From the high lands North of the river come numerous springs and streams, the waters of which, on their approach to the river, are absorbed by the sand, and form marshes and bogs over which travel is almost impossible (except when they are frozen). The road on the north side of the North Fork is a sand bed or quagmire for almost the entire distance from Supply to Reno, and the cost and delay in supplying a Military Post by this route, are in themselves most serious arguments against the location of any considerable force on the north bank.  The prevailing winds in summer and Autumn are from the South- These must come to a Post of cantonment on North bank -laden with all the Malarious and deleterious influences derived from the wide marshes over which they must pass before reaching the Post. In my opinion no position on the north bank can be healthy, and this must

3
be an insuperable objection to locating the Cantonment or Post on that bank.  The South bank offers many advantages.  There is little or no sand, and a post on that side can be supplied easily and surely by a good road at any season of the year.  The Marshes being all on the North side, there is nothing to affect the health of troops located on south side.  The timber is best and most abundant on north side.  The hay bottoms are nearly all on south side.

  There is but one really good site for a Cantonment or Post on North side. It is just at Meridian's Spring.  Its advantages are - that it is strategically on proper side of river - on high dry well drained prairie of good dark soil, good southern exposure- protected on north by sand hills and black-jack timber. Cooler in summer, warmer in winter than any site on South side-  water of spring excellent.  Cotton wood, Elm, black-jack, Walnut, Cedar and other timber abundant and near-  Disadvantages- Is nearly a mile from river. The water of spring hardly

4
sufficient for all purposes. The road from Fort Supply on North side is well nigh impassable for ten months in the year. A Post here must be supplied either from Wichita or by road on south side, involving long delays during high water unless the North Fork is bridged.  The springs which come out of the high bank south and south east of proposed site form a large Slough, which though a mile or more to the south east will surely breed miasma. (See topographical sketches No 1).   Opposite to this position on south bank of river is another fairly good site.  Advantages - It is directly on bank of river, above any overflow on a broad hard prairie with gentle slope towards river.  Nothing in vicinity to induce Malaria (except the slough a mile to the north east on other bank of river).  Easily and surely in communication with Fort Supply at all seasons by a good road. Hay being near.  Cottonwood fairly plenty - Disadvantages- Site too low and without sufficient drainage.

5
exposed to North. Sheltered from south winds. Hot in summer cold in winter. Comparatively little timber for several miles on south side. 

  Each of the above described sites for Posts has a good site for a cantonment within a mile. About two miles south West from Barrel Springs the river runs abruptly against a bluff bank from fifty to seventy feet high, and then goes off at an acute angle to the eastward. The highland forming these bluffs is cut by ravines into regular spaces, each sufficiently roomy for a large Post. These are in my opinion the best site for a Post to be found on the North Fork of Canadian   Advantages. High dry well drained prairie seventy to one hundred feet above river. Red clay soil. From their elevation they are exposed to winds from every direction and ought to be perfectly healthy. There are several slopes, all well adapted for a Post. All very near river. Nos. 1&2

6
and 4 & 5 are separated by running brooks of pure water. Good hay bottom directly in front of sites. Black-jack timber plenty and near. Chapman says excellent building stone is to be found on divide two to five miles south. Good road to Supply. Disadvantages. Strategically on wrong side of river, very little cottonwood or other timber (except black-jack) in immediate vicinity. Directly in front to northward is a heavy slough, above five miles directly to eastward is another very large slough. I do not believe these will affect the health of the troops at the post, but the question should be decided by one more skillled in Hygiene than myself. There is no very good place for a cantonment near these sites (See topographical sketch No. 2). Several fair sites for a Post were found on Serapin Creek, north of Barrel Springs, but the difficulty of getting at them in the extraordinarily broken country, and the execrable water

7
preclude any idea of putting a Post or Cantonment on that stream  The [?Cimarron?] River is the worst stream within my knowledge.  Its course is through & vast deposit of gypsum, salt ,&c, It tributaries from the south below the Mouth of Buffalo Creek are almost without exception, not simply unpalatable but unwholesome, bringing on serious inflammation of the alimentary canal.  The tributaries on North side east of Buffalo Creek, are almost as bad.  The North bank of the Cimarron is occupied by a Sand-Stream, quite as bad but not so continuous as that on North Fork.  The Marshes are just as bad .  Malaria and Mosquitoes are said to be worse.  The river itself, for the most of its course below the mouth of Buffalo Creek is a bed, varying from half a mile to three miles in width, carrying in most places in ordinary dry weather, scarcely any surface stream.  This bed is filled with sand and Clay.  The washings of the gypsum hills

8
and is not passable for wagons except by accident at any time or place.  Horsemen may struggle across almost anywhere, but nowhere without encountering dangerous quick sands.  There is not to my knowledge, or as far as I can ascertain from questioning scouts, and other persons perfectly familiar with the country, a single spot on the Cimarron , below the Mouth of Buffalo Creek, where it would not be simply inhuman to station troops  Actuated by strategical considerations, I had hoped to find on Eagle Chief Creek a good site for a Cantonment and Post, and still think it probable that such a site may be found.  I was deterred from attempting to follow up this stream (as was my intention) by the broken nature of the Country, the scarcity of palatable water, and the depth of snow.  There are good springs near the Creek but the water of the Main stream

9
is bad.  there is very little wood, sand hills predominate on one bank.  on the other the soil is light and thin. completely riddled with gopher holes, and there is no grass.

  The best site for the Cantonment and Post in my judgement, is some one of the high plateaux South of Barrel Spring. On South bank of North Fork, I cannot recommend any exact location. That must be determined by a future examination under more favorable circumstances.  All the places looked well. but it is impossible to decide which of several sites is best when all are covered with a depth of snow.  As all are near together the future selection of the exact location will be a simple matter of a few hours of survey and study.

Very Respectfully

Your obedient Servant.

1. 
Itinerary of trip in search of site for New Post  ---from Camp Supply.
Jany 6th 1879 - Monday,
Left Camp Supply Marched nearly N.E. between Beaver & Wolf for 1 mile. Then crossed Wolf Ck.  Thence nearly East 3 miles crossed North Fork.  Thence S.E. 4 miles to Lee & Reynolds Ranch-  The North side of N. Fork (after Beaver & Wolf come together) is a mass of sand hills. sometimes in ranges but generally without order -  3 miles from crossing of N Fork, a little stream takes its rise in the sand hills & after a course of a mile sinks -  Camped on this stream.  Good water - plenty of wood & grass in season- I  [unclear]        [?pony?] Terrible storm at night, from South 
Distance 8 miles-
Jan,y 7th 1879 Tuesday-
Wind lulled about midnight. Marched in a generally S.E. direction though the road was exceedingly crooked by reason of Sand Hills - In 8 miles I arrived at another Cattle Ranche of Lee & Reynolds. situated on a beautiful

2
spot between two lovely little brooks  which taking their rise in the sand hills flow together, after a course of a mile or two- and form a marsh-  In spite of the terrible weather, these streams are entirely open.  (the river being every where covered with 8-10 inches of ice -)  It is a splendid camping ground - abundant & delicious water, plenty of wood & grass in season-  This ranche is not on the usually travelled road- I came by it to get hay-  Stopped an hour and [?frescoed?] my wagons with huge bundles - as much as I could haul -  Continued down the river by a [blind?] & not good road for about 8 miles-  At least two miles of this distance was across prairie- marshy impassible when not frozen-  The usually travelled road north side goes around through the sand hills & is longer -- About 8 miles from the Ranche I struck the regular road south side at the 22 mile crossing of North Fork-  Continued down river about 4 miles, and camped on the northernmost of a series of spring holes and sloughs

3.
Called the Arrapaho Springs-  There is a swale running stream north of road and another evidently the same on south side. tho' there is no evidence of water  not even a depression on the road itself-  The storm of last night changed about noon today into a norther, & it has been blowing a gale & snowing fast all afternoon.  To obtain shelter I went in around the head of the right hand (south) stream and camped in the edge of a dense thicket on the river-  A most excellent camp- water on both sides, abundance of wood-  and good grass in season-  perfectly sheltered, for though the wind is howling furiously through the tree tops, not a bit of it strikes us -
Distance 20 miles- The road on N. side of N. Fork is not often travelled-  because of marshes impassible in summer  It is a good route much the best in fact in winter as sheltered camping grounds are frequent along the whole route- Just at the point where the river makes its bend from E. to S.E. there is, a mile to the northward, a deep grooved canon

4.
Called Oak Cañon -  It is six or eight miles long & has a fair stream of water which however sinks in the sand hills a mile from the river  reappearing in the form of a marsh-  one of those impassable except when frozen.  The streams, where Lee & Reynolds lower ranch is are [unclear] but that spot was called before the Cattle men spoilt it "St George's Roost" & was a great resort for turkeys-
Wednesday Jany 8th 1879-
Cold and cloudy-  The Arrapahoe springs consist of three sloughs (two of which have permanent water) and two very large fine springs.  These springs are unfortunately in the sand hills away from timber -  From my camp of last night on the most northerly of the Arrapahoe springs to the most southerly one is about two (2) miles-  The "( large spring" on the map is one of these and is correctly located -  Five miles from Camp we reached "Taylors River" a nice little brook of good water The vicinity has fine grass & is well wooded-  It is an excellent Camp ground-  Two miles from Taylor's River we came to the first of several

5.
springs. They are a few hundred yards apart pure & excellent water. Abundant wood and grass- These are called the Osage springs & are favorite camping grounds-

   From there we traveled over a long stretch of dry prairie & sand hills for about sixteen miles to "Cottonwood Grove" - Water comes out of the sand hills & joins a wide slough in which there is always water- In summer the crossing is very miry & bad. but the slough is easily turned- A small grove of cotton wood stands on south side of the slough - gives the name.  Four miles from Cottonwood grove the road passes within a few hundred yards of a slough on the banks of which is a very heavy growth of timber - Five miles further on we reached our destination for today "Sheridan's Springs" Several large fine springs of pure water come out from a high bank giving birth to a dense thicket of tall trees.  This is "Sheridan's Roost"  I am encamped at the first or most northerly spring the largest- It rises at the west-end of the timber & runs west or away

6.
from it - It runs only about a hundred yards & sinks- Two hundred yards east is another spring, equally good water but not nearly so large- "Sheridan's Roost" is the name given to a belt of tall timber extending for two miles [several sentences crossed through] It is not on the river. From Taylor's river to "Naked Bend" the road is everywhere separated from the river by from one half to four miles of distance & by a heavy range of sand Hills- Just here Sheridan's Roost the river is about a mile off   On the maps the two principal creeks of South side are correctly located but misnamed-  The creek called [Catherin?] on the map is really Persimmon.  & that called persimmon is [Catherin?],  The persimmon is small with good water. The [ Catherin?] considerably larger water bad.
Distance today 32 miles- cleared off late, & the night is beautifully clear but very cold-
Thursday Jany 9th 1879-
Did not move camp-

7.
Friday Jan. y. 10th 1879
Through sand hills for about 5 miles, then across a broad flat. At about 6 miles from camp of Yesterday we came to the river at a place called "Naked Bend". there not being a stick of timber or even brush.  All the country hereabouts is flat and though not subject to overflow from the river becomes in the spring a huge lake or series of lakes.
Barrel springs 8 miles from Sheridan's Roost & 2 from Naked Bend, is a slough with some timber, There is no palatable water at this season, but the springs are said to be good water when open.  The Slough is a horrible bog in spring & summer. Left road at Barrel Springs & went down about 2 miles . Camped on river near some fine looking sites for post on south side. which I wished to examine.  Distance 10 miles-
The map sent me is remarkably accurate so far as it goes.  considering the small scale.
There is one great advantage in the terribly cold weather.  I can cross the river any where & have done so on horseback many times.  yesterday and today.

8
Saturday- Jany 11th 1878 [1879?]
Marched due North crossing road in a mile & about a mile to the east of Barrel Springs. In another Mile & a half we struck the Black jack timber  Got along in this very well (though by a very crooked route as we had to turn & twist as we found openings ) until we had made about 6 miles from camp. when we struck one of the most infernal pieces of country I have ever taken wagons through.  Tremendous ravines of sharp cañons almost impassable even if bare of timber, & every possible opening full of trees & brush-  Chapman worked like a beaver.  I got on my horse & rode everywhere.  There was nothing to do but keep turning the ravines until we should find a divide down which we could go.  The day was cloudy very cold, with spits of snow.  We got into a pocket from which we had to back out & going with Chapman to the top of a knoll I could see on my left front a series of deep Cañons with almost perpendicular sides- On my right from a long stretch of apparently level prairie stretched off to a River.  "That's our course" I said to Chapman.  We will go down that open slope & then strike up the river to Eagle Chief"  "Well but Col" said Chapman that's the North fork you are looking at "-- I was completely turned around-  We pulled out of the pocket. & kept turning ravines as we came to them.  After some time, I remarked to Chapman that I must be terribly turned around as I thought he was going wrong.

9. 
He pulled out his compass, not to satisfy himself but to convince me. gave one look at it & "looked sick"  He was going due south -- We got onto our course & in a little while struck our own trail-  We had made a circuit of about one hour.
After immense difficulty & many minor accidents ( if breaking [?bounds?] is minor) we forced ourselves down into the Cañon with axe & spade.  Crossed & went into camp to refit.  We are through the timber & anticipate no very serious trouble tomorrow. but it is one of the very worst Countries I have every taken wagons over-  I had no means of making a survey of the route, which I am sorry for as the map is totally unreliable here-  The creek runs, from where we struck it to some miles below us almost due east. then turns N.E.
The Cañons have fine timber Cedar & Oak some very large trees & there is an abundance of coarse stone.  There are some fairly good sites for a post on this Creek. Called Terrapin by the Indians but the water is bad strongly impregnated with Gypsum. Many Indians hunting in the Cañons some are in our camp (Cheyennes) 10 miles-

10
Sunday Jany 12, 1879.          
Search for a divide at once - Marching west of North- In about 2 miles got one. & followed it down without difficulty- though our march was very slow. the snow being sometimes up to the horses' knees & very hard.  The topography of map very defective-  There is a marked bluffy limit to the high lands from Glass Mountain S.E. I passed it about 7 miles from Cimarron- Crossed that river just below mouth of Glass Mt Creek.  The water is so salt that it freezes with difficulty & we came near sticking.  The bed is here 1/2 mile wide quick sands in open weather-  Glass Mt Ck. is a good sized stream.  Water very impure.  Eagle Chief Ck.is a bed about 75 feet wide through which runs a stream now about 20 feet wide 10 to 12 inches deep The water is clear & pretty to look at but very bad to the taste.  The west side of Eagle Chief to & up the Cimmaron for some miles is an endless succession of sand hills.  The east side is higher.  The soil is a loose mixture of sand and red earth miry & bad.  It is everywhere perforated with innumerable gopher holes

11
My camp is close on the East bank of Eagle Chief & directly across a bluff bank of about 50 feet from which come several fine springs of pure water.  I was greatly in hopes of finding a good site for a post on this creek- Chapman says this is the very best site on the creek.  The soil is not suitable- there is an insufficiency of wood on this side Cimarron & the stream is impassible for wagons 10 months out  of 12. There is no hay nearer than 12 or 15 miles & the hauling would have to be done over horrible sloughs.  No stone within many miles on this side River.  Except a few springs there is no good water in the whole country North or South of Cimarron (tributaries) from Bluff Creek on N.W. to Turkey Ck S.E.  This site is the one I had hoped to be able to recommend, but it wont do at all- On the Cimarron itself I wouldn't   condemn my worst enemy to live.  No conception can be formed of the steril dreary waste of sand & swamp in summer according to Chapman obscured from sight by day. by dense

12
clouds of acrid dust-- & at night made lively by the hum of myriads of mosquitoes. If all accounts are true ( & I don't doubt them in the least after seeing the River) Danté ought to have known the Cimarron & put it in his poem as a compartment of Hell.  I have not seen a single spot since I left the North Fork which would in any way be suitable for a cantonment of six comp's in winter.

 Monday January 13th 1879

Started back on return trail. the more eagerly that it had been thawing through the night & I had to cross the worst stream in America.  As I feared, the first wagon broke through & in five minutes the wheel mules were up to their backs in water & quicksand.  Got them out, unloaded wagons, hitched on more mules in front & after an hour of hard work got all over without serious damage.  Kept my trail as long as possible on return (not that it was the best or nearest route, tho it subsequently turned out to be best) but because the mules travelled easier & better over the broken road.  the snow is yet very deep in places.

13.
Instead of following our tortuous route back across Terrapin, I stuck to the divide.  The difference between going up & down divides is well exemplified in this case.  It took two days of hard work to go down to Cimarron.  We came up easily & without difficulty in one.  The Black Jack Timber [unclear] just on the divide.  Avoiding the passage of any ravine however slight.  We came by a very crooked route - but in a generally very direct course to the very head of the ravines.  Then struck due south. We had some cutting to do in the timber, but got through very nicely. Once on the open I struck direct for Naked Bend where I camped.  Distance 25 miles. Made a sketch at night, which I showed to Chapman who pronounced it as good as if I has compass & chain.  Which is complimentary, even if not quite true.  At any rate It is much more correct than the map I am travelling by.  
Tuesday January 14, 1879.
Broke camp very early as I wish to reach Supply in two days.  About 9 AM it commenced to rain & has kept it up & is still at it - 11 PM.   Will make road bad & spoil crossing of river.  Camped at Osage Springs.  Distance 33 miles-  Have already given details of route.

14
Wednesday Jany 15 1879.
Horrible day. Rain sleet snow all together, driven by a blast from the furthest pole.  Crossed river without difficult on ice, and arrived safely at Supply.  
Could make no observations on route, the weather being too bad.  Distance 31 miles.

PO Box 585                                                                                                         Smithsonian Institution

     Lt. Col, Richard J Dodge                                                                                       Bureau of Ethnology. 
                    23rd U.S. Inf.                                                                                       Washington , D.C. Dec 1st 1879.
                       Fort Supply, 
                         I. T.   

Dear Sir:  

   In order to diminish the personal labor required to fulfil the request already made  to you on behalf of this Bureau for contribution to its work upon the Sign Language of the N.A. Indians, I have the honor to mail herewith a number of sheets giving outlines of body and arms and of typical positions of hand and fingers, which can be used as bases for alteration and reference and will be furnished in larger supplies if desired.  A sheet of examples of the proposed mode of using those forms is also enclosed, and a revised List of Signs prepared to suggest inquiry or refresh memory.  It is desirable that both the figured illustrations and a clear written description shall be employed, each tending to supplement and explain the other, and when striking facial changes or emotional postures seem to individualize or accentuate the gesture, notice of them in the written description would be important.  The sheets can also be used for successive signs forming a speech or story, being cut and pasted in the proper order to show native syntax.
    In continued hope that this Bureau will have the benefit of your assistance and that its publication may be mailed to you enriched by your contribution,   

I Remain 
Very Respectfully Yours,

Garrick Mallery

Bvt. Lt. Col.  U.S. Army.

My Dear Husband,
Accept my most heartfelt and grateful thanks, for your most generous and welcome +mas present to myself and our dear Son. We intend to do just what you advise and wish us to do; spend it upon ourselves, in getting necessary clothing, which both need. I cannot and have not made +mas presents since my severe reverse of fortune, and it is a real disappointment to me, that I was not able to give +mas gifts to the few relatives and friends, who have remained loyal to us in our adversity .-  I have this satisfaction though, that they all know just how I am situated and therefore I 
[across top]
so much like to see you, dear Richie, and wish that you could and would arrange it, so that you, and I, might meet, my dear husband and have a visit together  It would give me much pleasure to see your dear kind, face again.  Instead of looking at your large picture, I have handsomely framed, in our library   With much love and kisses for yourself, and love to Laura. Good bye, God bless and keep you, safe and well.  
Your affectionate wife 
Julia R.P. Dodge

being very much inspired by these moderate priced Theatres. - I think the popular Theatres in a very few years, will force down to the same basis, nearly all our high priced Theatres in most of the cities, throughout the Country. - If Fred does only an average fair business, his first season, his profits, after all his expenses are paid, each week, would be two hundred dollars. - Fred has been permitted to carefully examine the books of last season, of the Manager, who had offered him, the twenty weeks for next year. - So Fred has seen, what profits came to Manager and Star. - Then another advantage to dear Fred, would be, that he can take four solid, good, months of rest with you, each summer. - I expect to leave home on Thursday night, the 20th of December, and join dear Fred, at Atlanta, to go through the South; the traveling will be hard, as we have many two nights stands. - I would

[Note at top]: The bird book is forwarded by mail today

                                                                                          Smithsonian Institution,
                                                                                      Washington, D. C. , March 22, 1880

Dear Sir,
I am in receipt-of your letter of the 12th of March asking for a copy of the History of N. American Birds by Baird and Copon? & in reply by to say that if I can procure a copy I will send it, with a great deal of pleasure.  A much more exhaustive treatise in North American birds is that published by Little, Brown & Co Boston, five or six years ago, entitled History of North American Birds, by Baird, Brewer & Ridgway. This is well illustrated, & much more up to the times. but unfortunately only covers the Land Birds, the Water Species being yet to appear.

I shall be very glad to enter into correspondence with you upon matters of natural history, & while receiving such specimens as you can conveniently gather, I will send you publications bearing upon the subject. 

You will understand, of course, that with the limited number of copies of such works that we can afford to print, it is

necessary for us to bargain a little in the matter of distributing them.  but I think our correspondents will testify that we do our fair share, in the way of reciprocity.

We are not so much in need of the birds themselves as of the eggs.  Among our desiderata I may mention those of the Forked-tailed or Swallow-tailed Hawk, the Black -shouldered Hawk, the Mississippi Kite, the Paroquet, the large black cock Woodpecker, the Turkey Buzzard, the owls & a number of the warblers not that we are entirely without the species of any or all of these, but our representation is defective & not suited to the purposes of the National Museum.  The smaller mammals, particularly the field mice, moles, shrews etc. will be also very desirable, but perhaps more interesting to us, if anything, would be well preserved aboriginal relics in the form of pottery, pipes, scrapers, hammer stones & the like.  We have published a great deal on this subject which we shall be able to send you in return.  

Col. R. I. Dodge
Encampment                                                                          Yours Truly

  North Fork Canadian
            Indian Territory                                                            Spencer Baird

Smithsonian Institution Bureau of Ethnology J.W. Powell, in charge
P.O. Box 585  Washington D.C.  Ap 10 1880
Col. Richard I. Dodge 23rd Inf. USA Cantonment  I.T. 
Dear Sir, 
Prof. Baird told me sometime ago that he had mailed the ornithological work asked for. Hope it came all right. -  I now enclose copy of translation of signs reported by Prince Max of Wied, hoping it may be of use in connection with the assistance to this Bureau kindly promised by you. Besides other communication it may not be burdensome to make upon the printed sheets notes of your observations as to coincidence, difference and fuller detail of description and return them to me with such annotation. 
I remain very Resply Yours
Garrick Mallery

Smithsonian Institution Bureau of Ethnology J.W. Powell, in charge
P.O. Box 585  Washington D.C.  July 3d 1880
Col. Richard I. Dodge, 
23d U.S. Infty
Dear Sir: I am printing a small preliminary edition, not for publication, but for verification, correction, comparison and study of all the Indian Gesture Signs now collected by this Bureau. In this paper, which I will mail to you and which is to be worked over by my collaborators as well as myself for the final publication I wish to group the signs by Linguistic Families and Languages, and therefore beg that you will mention the tribe or tribes among which the signs kindly contributed in your letter to me were specially observed. Several of your descriptions are in the

“Introduction” which you received. I am much disappointed that your contribution is not larger, but still hope that you will furnish from the mass of material in your recollection, valuable items for the final work. 
Very Respectfully Yours, Garrick Mallery
Bvt. Lt. Col U.S. Army

Smithsonian Institution Bureau of Ethnology J.W. Powell, in charge
P.O. Box 585  Washington D.C.  July 6, 1880
Col. Richard I. Dodge 23 U.S. Inf Los Pinos Agency, Col
Dear Col.
I receive with your pleasure yours of 25th ult - and mail another copy of "Introduction” and set of blanks, as requested.

  Lieut Clark’s article - aimed at me to demolish - was in July No. of the United Service. The trouble with him is that he dont know what I am doing. He takes it for granted  1st that I have not personally seen any signs whereas the remarkable advantages here during the last year, nearly all tribes having sent deliga-

tions, has given me better facilities than many years in the field could have. The Secy of the Interior gives an order - and the Indians and interpreters are mine - for days or weeks - I have phonographers - photographers &c -

  2d - All my contributors - collaberators &c give the same diagrammatic illustrations by which vagueness of description is corrected.
  I am printing - privately - not for publication - the signs now collected - for verification, correction - study and comparison - before the final work and to perfect the latter -  will send you a copy - and beg that you will by return mail tell me in what tribe or tribes you noticed the signs already given in your letter - part of which was used in the "Introduction".  The arrangement will be by tribes.  Perhaps you will have some more signs to send on at once to the private edition.  I hope so.

Very sincerely Yours
Garrick Malleny

Smithsonian Institution
Washington, D.C. Oct. 25, 1880
Dear Sir, 
I beg to acknowledge with many thanks the receipt of the package of plants and flowers announced in your favor of the 23rd August. These were received in good condition; and, in fulfillment of an agreement entered into between the Smithsonian Institution and the Department of Agriculture, they will be transmitted to that Bureau with your name attached as donor. 

 We shall be very glad to have you continue your interest in collections, both of Natural History and Ethnological specimens, for the National Museum; and in return shall endeavor to procure for you any of the Government

publications which you may call for - especially those of recent date. 

 Again thanking you for your earnest in the way of helping us I remain

Very respectfully,
Sherman Baird
Secretary
Col. Richard I. Dodge,
Near Los Pinos Agency,
Colorado

SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION,
Bureau of Ethnology, 
J.W. POWELL, Director
P.O. Box 585.             Washington, D.C.,  Nov 18th 1880

Col. Richard I.  Dodge, U.S.A., Cantonment,  I.T. 
My Dear Sir, 
I take pleasure in acknowledging the receipt of your letter of the 28th, ult, and thank you for your promised assistance. Notwithstanding the pressure upon you in the work which you are preparing for the press, I hope that you will be able, if not to contribute new signs immediately, to attach to those already printed in my “Collection” and credited to yourself, the names of the several tribes from which they were procured. You will observe that in the absence of that specification the references to your authority occupy

an anomalous position. The reason for this special request is that I expect to prepare before January next another phase of my general work, which however will not be the final publication, but in which I will desire to use for illustration some of the signs contributed by you. 
Very Respectfully, Garrick Mallery
Bvt. Lt. Col., U.S.A.

Youth's Companion.
Boston
Sept. 22nd, 1882.
Dear Sir:-
Permit us to call your attention to the Youth's Companion a paper which circulates 270000 copies a week. and which includes among its writers many of the most prominent authors of both Great Britain and the

United States as you will see in the prospectus which we send you in a separate inclosure (sic). Being acquainted your interesting books in the Plains etc.,  we think that you could write something that would greatly entertain our readers, and we should be glad to have your name among our

contributors to the next volume. Will you not write two or three papers for us on The Boys of the Sioux or on the young people of any tribe which will afford you interesting material? Anecdotes illustrative of their games, their occupations, their duties etc. would be valuable. Each paper should not be

more than two pages of Harper's Magazine in length, and for each we would pay #35 if that amount would be entirely satisfactory to you. The style of the papers need not differ at all from that which you usually write, as The Companion is a family periodical and is not especially aimed for child-

ren.
In a book of mine called Boys in the Mountains and on the Plains, which will be published by Appletons shortly, I have taken the liberty of quoting a few paragraphs from you, giving of course full credit, and I shall  be glad to know

that you do not object to this.
Trusting that you will write for us, and that we shall have the pleasure of hearing from you soon,
I am, for
Perry Mason & Co.,
Yours Faithfully,
William H. Rideing
Col. Richard Irving Dodge,
U.S.A.

Youth's Companion.
Boston.
October 10th/82,
Dear Sir:
We are very glad that you consent to write for us, and we are sure that our readers will be charmed with what you have to tell them.  We do not wish to hurry you, but as we propose to announce your articles in our next prospectus we should like to have them in hand by the First of January

next. No doubt you will be settled in your new quarters before that time, and can let us have the Ms. 
We shall be glad to present our readers with a true picture of the condition of the Indians and we are fully in sympathy with your view, but you will readily understand that articles of a controversial character would scarcely suit a paper like ours. We hope that you will give us thrilling incidents of adventures

and of all that goes to make up life among the Indian boys and girls.
Among our projects for next year is a series of articles on Life at the Frontier Posts, wherein the commandants of the most distant military ouposts shall give details of their lives -- stories of deserters, frontiersmen, wild animals etc. You could, of course, write one on Fort Sully, and we shall be exceedingly

obliged to you if you will give us the names of other officers stationed elsewhere in the far West who have had interesting experiences and who could write them in a popular style.  Assuring you that if you will do us this favor we shall be very grateful, we are, dear Sir,
'Yours Faithfully,
Perry Mason & Co.
W.H.R.

Youth's Companion.
Boston.
November 28/82.
Dear Sir:
The articles which you have been kind enough to send us are interesting and valuable, but they are not exactly in our line, and we therefore return them to you, feeling sure that you will be able to use them elsewhere. What we want is incident - as thrilling and picturesque as possible, and we still hope that you

will write some adventure sketches for us, illustrating the lives of Indian boys and girls by anecdotes. The trouble with the matter now returned is that it is too ethnological, too philosophical and too controversial for us.  It will appropriately fit into some future book for which you have apparently designed it, but it is too mature in its qualities for us. Pardon us for speaking this frankly, as we do it believing

that if we can impart an idea of the matter we want there is no question of your ability to supply it.  We earnestly desire to have your name in our prospectus next year, knowing that it will attract many readers, and we therefore trust that we shall soon hear from you again.  We are, dear sir,
Yours very Sincerely,
Perry Mason & Co.,
per William H. Rideing,
To Col. R.I. Dodge

A. D. Worthington & Company, Publishers of Popular, Illustrated & Standard Books.  Sold only by subscription,
Hartford, Conn.  Oct 24th 1882

Col R. I. Dodge

    Dear Sir:

Yours of the 15th is at hand.  I am glad to know that the books went off so rapidly.
I have mailed and the lot today as ordered and enclose bill.  I trust they will reach you safely and
promptly.  Let the bill apply on a/c
It was an oversight in [?that?] writing my name in the Halfturkey copy sent with the last
lot.  I did not think anything about it at the time.  If you wish for a good copy to keep for yourself
let me send one from my new Edition in about four weeks.  The paper will be better, and a
new ed'n of Plates will be ready by that time.
The latter are printed but it will be three or four weeks before they are dry enough to use.
They are very handsome - the best yet.  So when this new Ed'n is ready I will
send you a handsome copy & put my fist on it.
I therefore change 7 on the one sent the other day at $3 - the regular price is #6.00
You can easily sell it with the others.  I want to work off the present Ed'n before beginning
on the one having better paper.  I have made a tremendous effort on the book.  The enclosed advertisement is now
running in about 1700 newspapers, and I have sent out circulars by the cart load.  I get a good
many responses from such a deal of advertising

but a great many of them are trash, and many more are from boys.  I have started
about 1000 Agents!  Such an army ought to accomplish much, but as yet it has not.  Agents go into
ecstacies over the Carevansering book and prophesy great things - but that is the last I hear from many of them.
The reports that do come in are small generally - occasionally a good one.  I do not know why
my agents do not accomplish more, unless it is that there has been so many cheap miserable blood
& thunder Indian books sold that the public have got tired of the whole business.
Those who do buy are perfectly satisfied with the book.  No one finds any fault with it.  The thousand agents
I have started ought to have sold 25 000 by this time instead of only a little over half that number.
I think I shall eventually scratch up to 20 000 - shall try mighty hard for it anyway.  I shall make nothing
on the book because I put so much money into it.  Few publishers would have brought it out
in the style I have.  If I get up to 20,000 I shall about get my money back counting nothing
for my time &c &c in handling it 20, 000 could never be sold through the trade.  I hope you will
work off many copies at your post through the sutler.   Let me hear how they go.
Yours very truly 
A.D. Worthington

My Dear Sir:-    

                                Your favor of 5th inst is at hand.  I will send the 20 copies "Our Wild Indian"

to Messr Queen & Young on Tuesday next.  I am entirely out of Colored Plates, the printer not getting

The same has been charged to your a/c
As soon as I can send you a first-class copy from this new Ed'n -  I will send it on as promised.
I want to send you a fine copy - one you can keep for yourself.
I recd a very polite & ceremonious enquiry from the Sec of War Robt T. Lincoln 
a few days since asking the price of "Our Wild Indians", and what price we would make on 150.
I made a special price, & a low one; but have heard nothing in reply.
Thank you very much for the order you send in.  If we can send from 30 to 50 copies to every

Hartford, Conn.  Dec 30th    1882

Col R I. Dodge
My dear Sir:-

                    Your favors of the 21, and 27th Nov were duly received.  Let me apologize for the great

delay in answering them.  They came just as the holiday trade had begun, & I was extremely busy.
I wanted to reply to them fully & I put the matter off from day to day until after Christmas, and knowing Settlement day
was then at hand I deferred the business until now.  I hope you will excuse the delay under these circumstances.  
In future I promise your letters prompt attention.

   I was surprised myself at the refusal of the Secy to order the books for the Army.  Your letter was

the first information I rec'd that he had so decided, as no reply was made to my letter to him offering the book at a
reduced price.  However, I am not sorry.  I like your suggestion about making the "traders" act as agents
and I shall go for them red hot.  I have not done anything about it yet, but now that the holiday rush
is over I will make an attack upon every post trader & show him how he can earn a dollar or two quickly
& easily.  I am satisfied we shall sell many more copies in this way than the 150 the Secy enquired about.
As soon as I get my circulars & all prepared I will send copies for you if you wish.
I have made up your a/c to date, and

2
inclose statement of the same.  The total number of books actually sent out to date is 19.659.
Of this number 1,587 copies have been given to promote the sale - leaving 18,072 copies on which royalty to you is due.
The royalty amounts to $1.807.20  The various sums charged to your a/c (as per statement) and the draft I now
inclose for $879.95 - balances the a/c exactly.
I hope you will find the statement correct & to your entire satisfaction.

     In explanation of the 1587 copies given away I would say that 127 of them were used for the sole

purpose of obtaining review from the large city papers, New York, Boston, Phil, &c & &c and 1460 were
used on the County newspapers.  I wanted to give the book such a lift as no book had ever before
rec'd, and every county newspaper in N.E, N.Y, Pa, N.J, Md & Del was written to, & a fine copy of the
work in Half Turkey binding was offered to the Editor of every paper who would insert our ad't on the terms
we named.  About 1000 accepted in the states above mentioned, and 460 accepted in the North Western
states through my Chicago Gen'l Agent to whom I supplied the books at cost to induce him to go into it.
My other General Agents would not adopt the scheme, on the ground that they could not see enough 
encouragement in the sale to warrant them going into the arrangement.  I hardly

3
think I got half of my money back again, but you may have the satisfaction of knowing that
every country paper of any size in the territory named, has recd a copy of "Our Wild Indians."
Many Editors took pains to write personal letters to me after the book was recd, in which they expressed their surprise
and admiration of the book.  They did not expect anything so good.

  By the way I recd a letter from Gen James S. Brisbin from Fort Keogh a fortnight ago in which

he has the "great honor to congratulate us on the production of Col Dodge's Indian book" &c &c and after
other complimentary remarks about the "mechanical execution" of the work, he wants to know if I will not
undertake the publication of a book he intends to write on "The Trees"!  He stipulates that we shall
bring it out in  "as handsome form as Col Dodges book"
I have not replied to his letter.  When I do I shall have to "decline" his book "with thanks"
And now Col.  I want to say a word about another matter.  I have made no money on "Our Wild Indians."
I have done my level best with it, and have given to its sale nearly one solid year of time, in which
I have exhausted every resource & plan I could devise to create a good sale.  I have succeeded

4
in working off very nearly 20.000 copies as you see, but this sale has been made at a tremendous cost
and the total sale thus far will hardly pay for these expenses & for the great expense incurred in getting up the book.
As near as I can figure it I shall come out about even, losing a years work and effort of my own, which might have counted for
something on some other book.  I put too much money into getting the work up to ever make one penny out of it.  The praise of friends and
enthusiastic newspaper notices do not put the cash into my pocket, however satisfactory those
things may be in another sense.  The sale is really about over.  I question whether I  shall ever bring
the number sold up to 22.000.  If I cannot do this I shall have a big stock of printed plates, cuts & chromes,
on hand & the result will be a round loss.  I have done everything I could think of to make sales, &
what are sold in the future will be sold here a few & there a few - the result of former advertising and
effort.  I know that you appreciate the style I brought your book out in; and I have, beside, paid you over
One thousand eight hundred dollars.  In view then of what you have received & the fact that the book has not been a profitable one to me, I ask you 
if you will surrender your claim to further

5
royalty & copyright on the book from this date and give me a chance to get out good & whole.
If you will do this I will do what more can be done to sell the book & this little service, of 10 [?] per copy
will help me out wonderfully.
I wish you would take the matter into consideration and let me know soon.   If you decline to do it I 
have no more to say.  To show you how earnestly I have pushed the book & the amount I have spent
upon it, I would mention one advertising contract alone of $3.800.00 in solid cash that I paid out,
to say nothing of a dozen other contracts for large sums.
I have sent about 15 or 20 copies to London, & several to Germany.  One German Editor at Stuttgard
requested a copy for special review in his paper - critical one I think - & of course I sent it at
once.  The Editors name was Dr. Ratzel.
Please let me hear from you, and write specially about the matter of surrendering your claim
for royalty in my favor, as that is an important item to me just now.
With the compliments of the season
I am Yours Very truly   A.D. Worthington

Hartford; Conn.  January 19th 1883

Col. Richard I. Dodge
My Dear Sir:-
Your favor of the 7th reached me only this day.  I presume it has been snowed in somewhere.
I note your order.  The books go forward today, by mail, as desired.  I am sorry they cannot reach you by 
the time you wish, but the delay has not been with me.

 I am sorry you cannot see your way clear to waive your interest in the copyright of the book.

I am not given to pessimism - at least I didn't know I was - & I have not painted the prospects of future sales
in an unfavorable light to induce you to accede to the request I made.  I merely stated the facts just as they
were.  The book has been out one year, & I have devoted my very best efforts, all my time, & spent no end of
money, to make a good sale.  The result is that something less than 20.000 copies have been sold.  This has not
paid me by any means.  The book was a very expensive one to bring out.  I put altogether too much money into
the Enterprise, and fixed the price of the Vol too low.  The book has certainly had Everything in its favor, but the 
big sale has not been made.  I do not know what
more I can now do to increase the sale.  Practically the sale is over - the cream was clean gone some
months ago.  I see that you think, evidently, that

the sale will continue.  I am sorry you think so, because you will be disappointed.  It is true, as you
say, that the royalty is a small sum.  My intention was, provided you had waived the royalty, to spend another
thousand dollars in giving the book a push.  I cannot afford to do it as it is, because the sales are not large 
enough & they own profit too small to warrant the outlay under the existing arrangement.
Really my time is worth more in pushing other books.  I have hung to "Our Wild Indians" with a vengeance and no
mistake, and I can assure you that Everything possible has been done to promote its sale.  I can do no more 
than has been done.

  You can rest assured that in the future I shall do all I can do to sell the book - it is for my interest to do that:

but it will  not pay me to make further special effort upon it.

  Enclosed find a letter rec'd this morning from a good agent who abandons the book for reasons given by himself.

I have lost quite a number of A. No 1 Agents for the same reasons.  I have never sent a copy
to a religious newspaper to review, because there can be no question as to their opinion on this point, and
the result would be very injurious to the sale of the book.  Favorable  reviews from the religious press
are a valuable auxiliary in making sales, but all help

from that source had to be abandoned from the very start.

  I shall be glad to supply copies of the book now to anyone who may apply for them, except that

I will not sell to booksellers.  If there are any of your friends who Complain because they cannot
obtain the book, they will be supplied from here upon application.

  You shall have that presentation copy as promised.  I have not forgotten it.  I intend to have

a copy bound for myself, and shall put one through with it for you.   I intend to get them done in New York and when ready will send you as handsome "Copy as you could wish for.
The Library books sent today are so marked on the back of the packages
Believe me to remain
Yours Very Truly
A.D Worthington

My Dear Sir:-

appreciate your views and am
much obliged to you for the

Danbury N.C
March 31st  1883
My dear Uncle-
I have examined your note, & in my
opinion, it is legally drawn & will accomplish
the purpose for which it is intended.
I enclose it to you, & hope it may reach
its destination safely - The mortgage is of
the same date but will have to be sent to
Nina & signed before it can be registered -
As I do not know how long you, Aunt
Mary or I may live, I made the mortgage
payable in five years with a proviso
in it however that if I fail to pay the interest
promptly, then it may be foreclosed before the end
of the five years, provided you wished it -

 I hope this may be satisfactory to you if however

you wish it written differently, let me know
& I will change it, as I made it payable in
five years, only because if you & Aunt Mary should die 
yr heirs might push me immediately.  I could

not in a limited time raise the principal, whereas having
a fixed time for the mortgage to fall due
I could make ready to pay.

 I am feeling very badly to-day from a severe

cold, in fact I ought not to be out so
please excuse all mistakes, bad-writing &c.
There is no news in the neighborhood, we
are catching some fine cat-fish & chubs
in the river - & as the legislature passed a 
law to remove the dams from across the
river, we hope to have some fine sport.
I have an itemized account of gr-mothers
funeral & medical expenses & other little matters
owing by her, & also an account of how I 
spent the $50 sent me by you, a copy of
which I will send you if you wish it, after
paying the expenses I turned the balance over
to Mother & Aunt Mary.
Hoping to see you sometimes during the
year, I am as ever
Yr Affec Nephew
R.B. Glenn

Hartford, Conn.  April 20th  1883

Dear Colonel

                      If our German friend wants a copy

of "Our Wild Indians" he can send me $3.50 and
25c additional for postage.  The cheek of these
"furriners" is amazing.
Well, how are you anyway?
I didn't know but you were scalped ere this, it is
so long since you wrote to me & you did not even
reply to my last letter.
I shall give the book another
extra push this Spring.  I have pushed it for
all it was worth all winter, but the progress has
been rather slow.  I am going to salt the
religious papers with copies for review, and 
run the chances.  They can't do much harm
now anyway.
I have a new book coming out this
Spring, and shall get in a last lick on "Indian"
at once, though I do not really expect great results.
Your Son played here with Margaret Mather a few
days ago, but I did not know it until I read the
criticisms in the papers.  Our newspaper gave him
high praise & I wish I had saved the notices for you.
I think your son ought to have called upon me.
Sincerely yours      A.D Worthington

Dear Sir
Yrs of 15th just received. I wish you to settle the estate of Mrs Maria Paulding just as soon as possible. You tell me that you have mortgage representing  $3000. If I recollect rightly the will distributes $1700 as special legacy - $500 to me & $200 each to six nephews & nieces. There should be no debt whatever. After those legacies are paid the residue of the estate belongs to my wife Mrs Julia P. Dodge & should be paid to her. It appears however that she has immediate & most pressing need of $1000, & on Oct 14 she sent me for signature a deed & mortgage (which I enclose you) asking me to sign - for her benefit.

This I then declined to do as I had no certainty as to how the estate stands - On yr statement that you have $3000 in mortgages I have concluded to sign these papers & send them to you for use or not as the condition of the estate shall warrant. If after examination of the will you have sufficient to pay the legacy over & above this $1000. you may at once hand these papers to Mrs Dodge. If there is not sufficient -  hold on to these - Please get a statement from Mr Jordan in the nature of a receipt on file for payment for his services - The interest of Mrs P.s estate was a little over $700 pr yr. $600 a year was to be paid her sister during her life - Mr. Jordan agreed to take charge of the estate for the difference - but as there was no agreement in writing I am aware that he may present a bill -

Jan 7th  The weather has been so bad could not send to mail this, snow over every thing & thermometer -2 deg below zero. That is hardly a start towards cold weather with you tho'    JD"
Laura 1 [?]
Jan. 4th '84
My dear Uncle,
I have wished for some time to write to you but have been so busy I have been too tired to write at night, but I received yr very kind letter a few days since & tho' I have been at the [?plane bed?] at work all day I intend to try & write to night tho' I may be inflicting a very dull epistle upon you.

  Bob told me you had some money to lend & he offered to lend to me on a mortgage, but after words said you objected to lending me as you said when the interest was due it must be paid or the money had to be made

Mr. Carter is very anxious to lend me the money & so are a great many others as it is such a safe & sure investment, as the land is worth six times as much as I am & it is hard to invest money at 8 percent on such a sure basis. I wanted the money from you simply because I would have such a long time to pay the principle & would not be uneasy about being jumped about it if any one died & the very reason you objected to lending me was the very reason I wished it - because if the interest was paid the debt could never increase, & if I knew the interest had to be paid positively on a certain day, it would always be paid

for every thing would be secondary to that & a man who was any account would always meet it if he had to strain & pinch to do so.  So if you have the money I will take a part of it (2500 or 3000) as soon as I know exactly my part of debt - I will give you a mortgage & a extra stringent clause about interest, I should like to pay it every year about July & if I get the money now intend to pay the interest from now till 1st July at that time. Ed & his bride left to day they spent a week with us, we liked his wife very much.  Mother came with them & will stay until next week.  I wish you were here to hunt squirrels

I can clean you up with the rifle, I killed five off hand at five shots & hit every one exactly where I aimed. The woods are full of them tho' I fear they will all leave soon or get killed out.
Birds are plenty tho' they are mostly in woods now. I have worked so hard this (last) year that I have had no chance to hunt much & would like to give you a round.  Crops were not good last year too dry for corn & dry so long no one could plant tobacco, tho' I hope I lost no money. The rail road is to Leaksville now so we are quite in the world. Excuse this letter. All send love
as ever Yr affec nephew J.D.G.

Fort Sully Dac. Ty
Jany 13, 1884
My Dear Jim,
Your very pleasant & acceptable letter of 4th is just recd.

In regard to the money matter, you will recollect that I am not making an ordinary investment but providing as safely as human action or human foresight can, for the support of my unfortunate sister in case of my death.

Personally there is no one on earth to whom I would more willingly lend (when the loan is in the nature of help) than to you but as this loan is for the benefit of another the very affection I have for you is a reason for hesitation in lending.  With a man for whom I had no special affection I could demand my interest or forclose, but it would be so great a trial to forclose on you that I might be put to serious straights by your failure to pay interest, before proceeding to that extremity.

you will naturally argue. "you loaned to Bob on the same security then why not to me "?--
The answer is as natural.  Bob is a Lawyer constantly handling & making money independent of season-  You are a farmer dependent on crops.  One or two good fees enable Bob to pay his interest. but one very bad season would prevent your doing so &( if I were dead) put poor Molly in the greatest straights.  Were I investing for money alone I can lend all I can save to farmers about here at 20 or 25 per cent. The regular sharps are doing this all the time, & the favorite quarry of these sharps are farmers.  because sooner or later a crop fails  & then the farm is taken by the sharp.  But I am in no such business. I want an investment. a perfectly safe investment at fair interest/ & I have no care as to how long the investment

may run ( except that the longer the better) provided the interest is paid promptly.
[following paragraph *-* has an X drawn through it}

I think I know you thoroughly,  I fully appreciate your honesty integrity & uprightness, but with all your hard work , you are not a "fore handed" or money making man.  You are too free with you money, too careless of little things & have too many kind neighbors to make demands on you & eat you out of house & home. *
 I know perfectly well that I am perfectly safe in lending you any reasonable amt, of money on a mortgage on your farm.  but I have so much affection for you & believe you have so much for me that I am loath to risk any loss of our affection by mixing it up with money matters.  I have said all this because I want you clearly to understand all my reasons for heretofore excusing myself from lending you money.-

I have felt it due to you & to myself to be perfectly frank. that our affectionate relations be not disturbed.  And now to business pure & simple I have the prospect of an investment in some coal lands which may (or not) prove very valuable.  You want your money about the 1st (say ) of July.  By that time if nothing happens, I will have $2000 or $3000 which I can let you have ( besides making the coal investment) It must be understood that the loan to you is for the benefit of Sis Molly, & that the payment or non payment of interest is to be a purely business transaction & must in no way disturb our affectionate situation, no matter what action may be necessary in the business. Bob is my trustee & atty, & with this understanding all round, I can let you have the money.

Letterhead of A D Worthington & Company
Publishers of Subscription Books
Hartford, Conn. Jany 17th 1884
Col. R.I.Dodge
Dear Sir:
Inclosed please find statement of a/c to January 1st 1884, and a draft to your order for $614.50 in full settlement for royalty on "Our Wild Indians" for the last six months.
Most of the books accounted for in this statement were sold during the first half of the six months. The sale has dropped off greatly in the past three months; indeed, for the past month I have scarcely sold 154 copies.  Practically the sale of the book is now over, and it is not likely that the returns next July will exceed 500 copies, as things look now.  I find I have sold or disposed of nearly 37,000 copies of this book. I think you ought to be pleased with the result. Mighty few books ever reach those figures. I have pushed it and done my level best with it.
I inclose circular of "Our Famous Women", my new book - a decided contrast to "Our Wild Indians", in subject. I brought it out last fall, and it is now selling fairly well, though business of all kinds is completely stagnant. 

   When you kill a real good big buffalo please have him carefully skinned and send me the robe for my sleigh. I would like him shot through the touchhole so that the robe will be entirely whole.

With best wishes for your health believe me
Yours Respectfully  A.D. Worthington

Letterhead of A.D. Worthington & Company
Publishers of Subscription Books.
Hartford, Conn. March 10th 1884
Col. R.I. Dodge
Dear Sir:-
Yours of 27th came promptly to hand.
Today I received the buffalo robe safely, and I thank you most sincerely for it.  In asking you to send me a robe I did not mean to be understood as asking you to give it to me, much less of robbing you of a skin you had procured for your own use, and which I am sure you prized.  I was willing and expected to pay for it.  I thought that by sending to you I should be sure of getting a real good one; and, of course, like the majority of Eastern people, I supposed choice robes might be very easily obtained almost anywhere among the Indians.

  I have shown the robe to several of my friends, all of whom pronounce it a most excellent one, and they are without exception surprised at the softness of the skin.  I am delighted with it myself, and shall always prize it for its giver and for the pleasant associations it will always recall.
   I will have a copy of the book bound in the best manner I can possibly get it done in at our bindery here.  I wont promise that it will be as finely bound as the copy I sent to you.  I sent the sheets of that copy and of another one for my own library, to one of the

best binders in New York.  Every thing about the binding is "handwork", and the vol would be considered by connoisseurs as a first-class specimen of fine binding. Our binders here say they can match it, however, so I have given them my copy to pattern after.

  It will give me great pleasure to send you a copy of "Our Famous Women", and I have ordered one bound in same style as the "Indian" now in hand, and please accept the same when you get it, with my compliments.  I will send both books to you in about ten days.
  It is highly gratifying to me to learn that you are pleased with the success of the book.  I don't know that I shall ever be able to bring the sale up to 40,000 but I would really like to do it.  It goes slow now.  I have done the best - the very best - I could with it, and spared no expense either in getting the vol up or in crowding its sale.  It has "taken the cake"  from every other "Indian" book published the past 30 or 40 years.  "Berden, the White Chief" - issued in the years when everything was booming and when it was just as easy to sell 10,000 books to 1000 now, made only 21.000; and it sold at a much less price than ours, too.  Buffalo Bill's book, issued only three years or so ago, sold about three or four thousand, though I believe if I could have had his book & been allowed to shape it, I could have made a great success of it.

He was here with his "show" about a year ago, and I called on him and presented him with a copy of "Our Wild Indians". His book, by the way, was wretchedly brought out; and while he expressed unbounded delight at the appears of our's, he did not conceal his intense disgust at the appearance of his own, though it is doubtful whether its shortcomings would have ever suggested themselves to him had he not seen "Our Wild Indians."

   By the way that minister - the Rev Wilson - was canvassed in Washington, beat me out of hundreds of dollars. He is a pill and no mistake. I never got a cent for the books he delivered in W. or anywhere else.

I trust you are better of the rheumatic attack & enjoying good health.
Believe me to remain
Sincerely Yours
A.D. Worthington

Fort Sully    D T

    July 17, 1884

My dear Boy,

 Yours of 14th reached me this p.m. & I shall wait for Saturday's mail with great anxiety.  You are worked up to so high a pitch of enthusiastic anticipation that a very slight reverse is apt to upset you.  I hope the best & allowing for youth you are yr Daddy's boy himself over again.  I get enthusiastic & ardent, work with all my might & mean to attain my end but if I fail there's an end to it.  I never worry & I believe you inherit that peculiarity to an extent that will save you from borrowing trouble. or taking trouble too much to heart.  I thought you were to open earlier & have been greatly disappointed when my papers gave no account of you.

2
At present we do not quarrel & there is nothing on my part to keep alive the animosity that she has exhibited towards me for some years.  If you now begin to urge reconciliation she will in true womanly perversity review in her own mind those old animosities now dormant or she will conclude that I am at the bottom of your appeal.  will hate me worse than ever, & you may possibly come in for ill feeling. as a dupe & tool of mine.  Be assured my dear boy, that I understand this matter better than you possibly can.  The only hope for future peace & reconciled life between us is to let her entirely alone.  I believe she has a strong womanly attachment for me, now & of late years obscured by diseased imaginings. If not fixed in her

by trying to turn her too suddenly these ill feelings will probably wear away with the disease.  The only hope of ever having her come back to her old time affection is to let her do it of her own accord.  If you push at her you will only do harm. I dont want her until she can come to me an affectionate wife, happy in me & contented with her lot.  I dont want her to come from love & deference to you or your wishes.  Dont mention this thing further in your letters to her.  speak of me kindly - affectionally as I know you feel.  but avoid arousing antagonism by appealing to her to make what she will probably regard as concessions to me.

I am not going East this winter.  so there is no need of annoying her.  If she is going to come around, time & good health may accomplish it. If not, not & thus the end of it.

3
I have nothing further of the progress of the demand on the 
Rhinelanders. I got a short note from Mr. Ward agreeing to the terms
which I demanded of him - that is, he to do all the work - be at all the
expense take all the risks for our half the gross sum recovered - your Mother
on no account to be called on for payment of any money whatever
in the shape of fees or charges.
I hope she understands this perfectly & will pay out no money in this affair.
Another thing of which I intend to write to her hereafter - in case you
cannot manage it for me, is this-
In July 1879 at your mothers earnest request, backed by solemn assurances

of Jordan, that the loan was to be only temporary, & to prevent breaking
in to her 8 per cent investments at Omaha I lent your mother $5.400.  This was in
4 per cent U.S, Bonds which I sold at par.
Had I held them until now they would be worth $6,600 besides the interest of 5
years - Subsequently I lent her $3000 which I had invested in Omaha &
still later $100.  making a total of $8.500 in Jany, 1881,   I got $1000 from Jordan.
On Jany.1.1882.  I took up her old note, & she & you gave me a joint note of $7.500
On June 30th 1882, you gave me another joint note for $500.
Now my point is this - If your Mother gains anything from the Rhinelanders
I think it but just & right that she pay me this eight thousand dollars
as soon as she gets it.  I am the oldest creditor & certainly should be the
preferred creditor.  I have never

4
recd a cent of interest on either note, & the other creditors have certainly
been paid interest or they would have brought suit.  The total interest due 
on the two notes is on the two notes is $1650, making a grand total due me of $9.650.00, 
(nine thousand six hundred & fifty dollars)
I do not want to say anything to her about this at present - but I do want
you to write as if of your own motion, speak to her of this debt & urge its 
payment out of the very first money she gets - I am not sanguine enough
to hope for a very large sum from the Rhinelanders.  They are a close money-
loving set & will squeeze hard.
I don't know how much she owes else where & I doubt if she does, so that
whatever she does get is likely soon

to be taken from her by Creditors.
I am the special creditor who should be paid first on my own account
and because whatever is paid me will be safe in my hands to go towards her
further support, in case the creditors get all the balance.
I rely on you to broach this matter to her, & to urge her to see that I 
am paid as soon as she has the money to do it.  Whatever her queerness - I know
she is honest & will see that I am paid if it is properly brought to her notice.
There is nothing new, all going on well.  We begin to look for Laura & Ida
soon, but have not heard when they will start.  With love & kisses
Yr Affec Father
Richd. I. Dodge.
P.S.  You are equally interested with your
mother in the payment of the two notes.
It gets a weight off your shoulders, &
gives me means to aid you more effectively 
when you need it.
R J D

Fort Sully     D. T.
                                                                                                                         Aug 3rd 1884

My dear Boy.
I wrote you a little note by St Hoyt. since which nothing exciting
or important has transpired.  Yesterday was my usual field day for the family &
all were out all day, resulting in a bag of 27 lovely young grouse - some too
large to broil - Joe & I together have bagged already this season 122 birds - I have never
seen such good grouse shooting anywhere.
I am much gratified with your success.
The papers try to make public opinion, & to little men it is always easier to find fault than
fairly to discriminate - And I am sorry to say that the very large majority of newspaper
reporters are very little men -  But the box office is the best critic, & after vainly
trying to keep a man down - these same little reporters will eventually join with exceptional
enthusiasm in the praises of that man who succeeds in spite of their abuse

The note of approval & admiration of Mr Jefferson, is truly a full compensation
for the abuse of every reporter in Chicago & will do you more good, than all their abuse
can do harm.  If not a breach of confidence -  (& I take it for granted that Mr. J's note was to be used at your own pleasure)
you should take occasion to get that note published in yr Theatre paper in N.Y
The favorable opinion of a man like Jefferson is worth money to an aspirant - & your
manager will fully appreciate the fact.
This is the last letter I shall direct to Chicago - as you will soon be gone - but I 
will write - to N.Y & also to Buffalo -
Let me have your dates as soon as possible.
Ed's wife has had a miscarriage, but is all right again.  He says he owes you a 
letter, & wants yr address, so I shall send it.
All send love.  Ida is entirely well, but has a scar over her right eye.  The post
is looking lovely, & I wish you were here to enjoy the hunting.
With love & kisses
yr affec Father
Richard I Dodge

Frederick Paulding
Leland Hotel
Chicago  Ills

[Letterhead of A. D. Worthington & Company]
Hartford, Conn.  Aug 28th 1884
Col. R. I. Dodge
Dear Sir:
Inclosed find statement of a/c At July 1st last, and a draft to your order for the
sum of One hundred fifty-eight & 11/100 dollars ($158.11)
in settlement of a/c as rendered.

  "Our Wild Indians" goes slow now-a-days, it has had its day.  I doubt whether I shall ever

reach the 40 thousand I hoped for.  An occasional order is the only business I have on it now, and these grow
more and more infrequent.

  I trust you will pardon the delay in making up your a/c this time.  It is due to the fact that

we have been excessively busy in pushing campaign books.  First we brought out Knox's "Lives of Blaine &
Logan"; and as we did not wish to be partial we afterwards brought out Barnums' "Lives of Cleveland & Hendricks"
We supply the books & the public may take its choice.  I inclose circulars of both books.

 I received a letter from M. A Townsend a few days ago.  He says he is post trader at Fort Sully,

and he wanted 6 copies of "Indians" sent on.  But he sent no money.  I have sent the books, however, and I suppose
he will pay for them.  When his order came we had no books on hand, and we had no cuts printed either.
I finally ventured to print an ed'n of 500 and had to wait

for it's completion before I could fill Townsend's order.  When a book has seen its best days we
have to be exceedingly careful not to get stuck with  a lot of printed sheets for which there is no demand to
speak of.  I can now fill all orders promptly so long as this ed'n lasts, and I presume it will be sufficient
for a year to come.

  I hope you are pleasantly situated at Fort Sully.  Please do not forget when you come across an extra fine robe, a painted one,

to buy it for me.

  Please acknowledge receipt of the remittance enclosed and believe me.

Yours very truly
A.D. Worthington

best for me & you that I keep away just at present.  All the Offs there know who you are & I think you will be well
rec'd though as the post is out of the City some six miles, you will not likely have much personal or social attention.
There is nothing new.  All are well & send love.  I am very busy building & you would scarcely recognize the post.
I will write again in a day or two to your next date - I am a  little afraid I am a little late for Buffalo.
With love & kisses
your affec father
Richard I.  Dodge

Fort Sully D. T.

My dear Boy

             The mail today brought me half a dozen papers, all attesting yr triumph.

I congratulate you with all my heart.  You are in the right kind of a Co. & with
the right kind of people for your future & if you keep yr health, I  have no fears -
You are bound to win fame & fortune if you work hard & take care of yourself.
Maj Wm  Smith - paymaster U.S.A left me today.  He is an accomplished &
agreeable gentleman, lives in St Paul & invited me to come & be his guest while
you are in St P.  He is a great friend of Maj. Schwan & wife who have
been at St P. paying the South a visit, & your advent is expected

Hartford, Conn.  Dec 2 1884
Col R. I. Dodge
Dear Sir
Your Post Trader, Mr. Townsend, don't pay up worth a cent.  You said you would
look after him if he didn't, so I inclose a statement of his a/c, and if you will see that a remittance is sent
to us pretty soon I shall be greatly obliged to you.
You will notice that his bill was contracted many months ago.  It is time it was paid.
Business is in a dreadful condition.  There is absolutely nothing doing, and the prospects ahead are not encouraging
to say the least.  I have not been so dull in five years as during the past six months.
Yours very truly
A.D. Worthington

Dear Sir:
Negotiations for a compromise of the above cause have been for some time pending and 
there is every probability that our terms will be accepted by the defendant at the next meeting of its directors.
In view of the difficulty of communicating with you, we think it well to save time by sending the deed to you
now as delay on our part may defeat a settlement.  We also send by this mail a deed to Mrs. Dodge.  
Please execute this deed before a Commissioner for the State of New
York if possible, if not, then before a Notary Public for Dakota and have his (the notary's) signature certified
by the Secretary or Governor of the Territory, the notary will explain the modus, if you should not be informed regarding
it.  Please return the deed as soon as possible.
There is little doubt of a fair compromise of this suit, and we may congratulate ourselves on scoring one victory.
Very truly yours
Edward Stephens
