My dear Husband,
I was very sorry to hear today, from your short note to our Son, that you were suffering so much, from that cruely painful disease Rheumatism.  Fred went out at once, on the receipt of your note, bought two boxes of the Salicilica  and then himself went to the Post Office, and sent them off to you this afternoon  When the remedy does you so much good, I am surprised you ever allow yourself to be with out it.  The medicine lost its beneficial effect upon me, the winter after our visit to you at Sully.

The most eminent Physicians, Specialists, in Europe and this Country all agree now; that Gout and Rheumatism, are essentially diseases of the blood; therefore treat the blood, purify it, and the disease will diminish rapidly.  Two years ago, I could not walk, without much pain, and limping, my joints were swolen, and my poor hands, almost helpless.  All the remedies Dr., Carman gave me were of little benefit.  I one day read in the World, a few lines from a gentleman, saying "he had been so wonderfully benefited, by the use of Agers Sarsaparilla, for Rheumatic Gout; that out of gratitude, he wished to make public, what that simple blood purificator had done for him.  This decided

me, to give it a trial;  After two weeks regularly takeing the medicine; a table-spoonfull, immediately after each meal, I began to feel better; the enlarged joints, all began to decrease, the pain in walking subsided.  I took it persistently for one year; then for five months, I felt so well I did not take it; but when ever I feel the pains comeing back, in my toes, and fingers, I resort to it, and always with the most beneficial results.  So do, I beg of you, my dear Rich, after the Salicilica, has put you on your feet; resort to my simple blood purifier, and keep yourself free from another attack.   Fred and I are both, much disappointed, that on account of your being obliged to be away so much this summer, we cannot come to visit you.  We had both looked for

ward, to such a pleasant visit to you, during the summer.  I hoped so much for Fred, from the rest and freedom from all care, which he always finds from visiting you; and the great comfort he takes, in your love, and companionship, while with you.  He looks thin and much out of health, and shows in his entire bearing he hard work, constant fatigueing travel, and all the annoyances of Mathers jealous, vindictive temper; have told heavily upon him.  Our case, has not yet, reached its turn on the callander, for a hearing before the Judges on the Court of Appeals, though each month brings us much nearer, the desired results of , our patient waiting.  I am glad you are so pleased with you new servant Eliza, I hope she, and Frank also will continue to be, most

[across top]
and annoying cruel treatment from Mather; looked very worn and out of health still.  I hope he will improve greatly, now he can rest and enjoy our dear home which is so comfortable.  I shall be very busy now, with a seamstress she  mending and cleaning all Fred's costumes then I do them all up on camphor and pack them away. it takes three weeks to do them nicely With much love and kisses, from us both, I remain your affectionate wife, Julia R. P. Dodge           
May 30th 1888

My Dear Husband,

I am very sorry to learn from your letter, received by our Son, day before yesterday.  That you are still suffering so much from your Rheumatism;  Fred and I are wondering and hopeing, you will be able yourself today, to take charge of the ceremonies, of this Decoration Day, and the dedication of the Monument,  to the Heroes of our War of 1812.  In your letter to me, in answer to mine, urgeing you to try; my Panacea, for Rheumatism; Agers Compound Extract of Sassaparilla.  You do not say, one word about, if you

are willing to try it;  it is so easy and pleasant to take, that  I wish you would give it , a fair trial of one month.  I think in two weeks, you will experience such benefit from it, that you will gladly persevere , in its daily use, for some months.  It is very gentle in its action, on the kidneys and bowels and through these natural channels, throws the impure blood, which occasions Gout, Rheumatism, and Neuralgia; gradualy out of the system.  I think you can continue the use of your Nitric Acid, as you ought to take that, just before eating; and the Sassaparilla, immediately after eating.  Our physician Dr. Carman, has the formula, from the Laboratory of, J.C. Ager; as the firm do not object to sending the Formula, to any reputable physician, who asks for it.  I will go over to see Dr. Carman,

and ask him, if you can take the Nitric Acid, with good effect and safety; during the time, you are takeing the Sassaparilla?  You know I suppose Nitric Acid, must not be continued too long, else like many other valuable remedies, it loses its good effect, and does positive harm, so be careful. I will send you, a few lines, as to what my Doctor says, about takeing these medicines, at the same time; as soon as I can see him.  Dr. Carman is now out of the City, for a few days rest;  he has a large exacting practice, and works harder, than he ought to do.  I am very glad, your servants are giveing you, so much satisfaction; they have a good comfortable home, just and kind treatment, not very hard work so I think they ought to do their best, to please yourself, and your good house.

keeper, Laura.  I am glad to hear, Laura keeps tolerably well; give Fred's and my love to her, and tell her, we both wish her; health, contentment, and a pleasant summer.  I am very grateful to all mighty God, for bestoweing upon our dear Son, such a fine position for next season; what a blessing and comfort it is that we can look forward to liveing in , our dear home next winter, and no traveling,  What a luxury.  Our dear Fred, has well earned, his position in Mr Hills esteem, and new Union Square Theatre; by his talents, integrity of life, and steady hard work, and perseverance during his past five years, under Mr. Hills management.  Dear Fred is begining to look and feel, rested and better; though the dear boy, from his long season of, nine months consant [sic] hard work, fatigueing travel,

Pawlet, Vermont. 
August 3rd 1888.
My dear Husband; 
Your kind welcome letter, was received early this week, and I was very glad to hear from you, and know you are feeling well; and that your great comfort, and most excellent housekeeper, Laura, is also well.  I thank you very much, and fully appreciate, your kind offer, to let me remain here, with our pleasant friends, the Berges.  I do not wish to remain , one moment, after dear Fred leaves, to go to visit you.  I do not feel that I'm improving at all, in this Mountain air; my appetite is very poor, and I do not take the least interest, in going out to try to exercise here;  because we are completely surrounded in this valley by hills and high Mountains, and I lose my breath so, that there is no comfort for me, off the piazza; on which I sit a great deal, out side of our nice cheerful rooms.  It is a great trial to me, being so utterly deprived from reading, by the Gout haveing affected the sight of my eyes;  thank God though, they are better, during the last six weeks,  then they have been for the past two years.  You

are right, in what you say, about mountain air, not agreeing with me, in my young days.  I long for the sea air, and hope soon to go ; where I can breathe it, and bathe in the Surf.  Fred will not allow me to go any where by myself, as he thinks it is too lonely, for me to be alone among strangers.  So I have written to our sweet little friend, Dollie Drumgold, who has been happily and comfortably married for the past four years.  to go with me to far Rockaway, it is reasonable the board, eight dollars for a small room, and ten dollars, for a comfortable room, per week.  Dollie said, when we left the City, she would like to go with me to the sea shore, when I was left alone, so I hope we can arrange to be together; as we are very fond of each other. Far Rockaway, has the advantage of being very near New York, only forty minutes, from the Brooklyn side, so her husband Mr. Ford, can come out in time for tea, every evening. An unexpected and most unwelcome telegram, has just been received, from Mr. Hill, summoning dear Fred to New York, to begin to rehearse on Monday, and begin [unclear] on Monday 27th of August.  We are both dreadfully disappointed, and annoyed, at Mr. Hills utter change of plans, for our Fred;  it is not fair or just to poor Fred, to begin to work him again so soon in the extreme of the summer.  Fred has written a dignified protest to Mr. Hill, reminding him of his promise to allow Fred to rest,

until the middle of September, or first of October I fear the letter, will not be of much avail, for the part is a strong one, and Mr. Hill told him, before we left the City, it would suit him very well; but then, Mr. Hill, did not intend bringing the play out until late in the Autumn.  Now Mr. Hill is impatient, at the delay necessary in finishing the Union Square Theatre, and has leased or rented, the Standard Theatre, so he can keep all his contracts, made for plays, and actors, to come out, at the Theatre that was burned. I fear dreadfully for Freds health, begining to work so early, in the extreme heat of New York; yet Fred dare not anger Hill, in refusing to play the part, if he insists, because his engagement to Mr. Hill, is one of the best, and most solid engagements, in the Theatrical profession.  Fred is very much worried, over the probability now, of his not being able to come to see you, and I am very sorry for both of you being disappointed.  Fred ought to have gone to visit you first, and so made sure of seeing you; but neither of us for a moment, thought that Mr., Hill, would call him back so soon, and cut him off, in his much needed rest.  I think it a great want of good judgement, in Mr. Hill, to open any Theatre in New York, before the 15th of September, when the cool evenings begin, and when at that date, all the very attrac-

[written on advertising card for Crescent Valley House Pawlet Vermont Leach & Crapo, Proprietors  E. A LeVene, Manager Gas, electric bells, hot and cold baths, good livery, fine billiard room, terms reasonable  Pawlet Vt.]
tractive sea shore resorts near New York close.  Manhattan Beach and Brighton Beach both the upper and tony end of Coney Island draw thousands of people every night to enjoy the delicious [evil?] down the Bay for an hour, delight in the cool braceing air, sit on the comfortable seats, an the grounds of the hotel, right close to the beach, and listen to most delicious music from the Military band, that plays at short intervals, all through the evening;  and all this comfort and pleasure, for fifty cents, the round trip.  The Theatres will not pay, until cool weather comes, and these other amusements are abandoned.  If we are obliged to return home, we will telegraph you at once.  With much love from Fred 
and myself and kisses from both of us.  Ever your aff wife.  Julia,
Fred and I both thank you very much , dear Rich, for your generous and much needed check.  God bless and keep you safe and well.

[across top]
were boarding is rapidly improving and becomeing [sic] a very beautiful country suburb, of New York City.  Give my love and Freds, to Laura, and tell her, we both hope, she will keep well, and be very happy all winter.  Remember us kindly to Sutright, I like him for his kind care of dear good, Joe, in his last sickness.  With warm love and kisses from Fred Your affectionate wife Julia R. Paulding Dodge. 
New York City
Oct. 12th 1888
My dear Husband,
We returned to our most comfortable and pretty home, here in Harlem, on Monday afternoon.  I was ever so glad to get back, to all my home comforts, and and [sic] Frances good cooking, and kind, attentive, thoughtful, care of me.  She is indeed, a most faithful and competent servant, in all our household work and duties, and most trustworthy, when we are away from our dear nest of comfort, which the home is; you and Fred, in love and generosity bestow upon me.  I am intensely interested, and to a certain extent, anxious, about our dear Sons important début, on Monday night, in the Modern Melo Drama, of Philip Herne.  I have no fear of our boy, in his performance of the fine character, of the part he is to play; his conception of the

man is most natural, and the deep touching tenderness Fred portrays, in the sad portoins [sic] of the play, go right to the heart.  Fred is very easy in the part, and at rehearsal yesterday, received most generous and hearty applause, from his company, and the old stage hands, which is very unusual.  This runs after his strong scene, with his Father and Mother, and when he gives the great raceing speech, which spoken with Freds fine elocution, and most expressive face and action; aught, and I believe it will, bring him, two calls before the curtain.  Mr. Hill is much pleased with the way Fred has rehearsed the part; he slapped him on the back and said, "You are all right in the part; go on and win success in it, before the foot lights; and I will do my full share of the work, as your Manager, in my Province."  What I fear is, that the critics, who are friends of Harworths, and like him, will try to injure Fred in some of the papers.  As the play has been fully criticised, by all the prominent news paper men, and had its grand opening; I doubt if they take much, or any notice, on Monday night, of Freds opening

in the part; because on that night, a new play is to be produced at the Broadway Theatre, and all the critics are bound by professional courtesy to be there.  Mr. Hill told Fred before the week was out, he would have all the best critics of the leading papers to see him.  The sale of seats only opened yesterday for Freds debut, and this afternoon Mr. Hill called to Fred, as he was leaveing the Theatre, to tell him, all the best seats in the house were sold, and the four lower stage boxes.  How much I do wish, you could come on to see us, and enjoy our boys success.  I hope very much, and so does Fred, that you will be able to join him and travel South with him a couple of months or more.  He does not know yet his route, or how soon they will start into the South.
Our case will be presented and argued over in the Supreme Court and the decision of the referee carefully examined, on our appeal, before it can be passed through to the Court of Appeals in Albany;  this preliminary is necessary,  and legal, but will only involve a few days, in

the second week in November.  I expect and am prepared to hear, that the Judges of the Supreme Court, will sustain the decision of the Referee, they usualy do on principal; because a Referee, is always one of their own appointing.  I am thoroughly hopeful and trustfull, as to the final and ultimate success of our great case;  when it goes to be heard and argued, before the Court of Appeals.  My case has been most wonderfuly and supernaturaly watched over and guarded, all through , and I place all my hope and confidence in Almighty God, and His Holy Angels, through devotions and prayers offered in His Holy Church and my own poor prayers.  All the most important proofs and evidence after long months of research by Mr. Ruddly and Mr. Stevens, were never found, until I fullfilled certain devotions and prayers in church,  in honor of, my own dear Guardian Angel.  Our Fred was very sick from his carbuncle, and suffered terribly from the pain, and intense inflamation all through the arm.  He had tremendous pluck and determination to play every night, as he did, for three weeks.  I improved immensely, all the time, I was in the pure, braceing salt air of Staten Island; during the last month, we were there.  I walked my four miles, every clear day. -  New Brighton where we

[across top]

ment, and her [unclear] Mr. Greenfield, will send you a check each month, for your rent? I hope you have had the beautiful fall weather at Madison Barracks we have enjoyed here for the past six weeks .  I hope yourself and Laura are feeling better and becoming accustomed to the climate.  Let me know how you both are, when you write.  With Love to yourself and Laura.  I remain your affectionate wife.  Julia


New York City
Oct. 23rd 1882
My dear Husband;  I had no intention or desire, to allow so long a time to elapse, without answering your last letter.  But for the past three weeks, I have been in much pain, nearly all the time from the effect of haveing, two nerves of back teeth treated, to prevent them from being killed, so as to fill the teeth. I have had an ear-ach, all the while, and constant head-ache; today I am almost free from pain, and the Dentist thinks, I will have no further trouble.  I have managed to write to Fred twice, during this period, but I did not tell

him, how much pain I was in, as I knew it would only worry him.  I am very sorry your coachman, turned out so badly.  Mrs. Webb must have been deceived in him also.  I have not felt able to get to see her yet.  I have been very quiet since I returned home, after my pleasant little visit to you, at your Post. When I first returned, I was busy every day, getting ready to join our dear Son; all through the month of September.  I never care to visit, or accept of invitations any more, since my loss of fortune; as I am too poor, to attempt to entertain, in any manner; so I live a perfectly quiet life; with peace and contentment in my soul.  I do love this pretty home, that you and dear Fred, allow me to keep, and I take clear comfort in it.  I have no news to give

you, almost all of the old friends of our early married life, that we used to visit together; are dead, or have moved away from New York City, to get rid of the heavy expenses, of haveing a home here.  Did you receive a present of Whiskey from Bleecher Rathbone; he and his wife Helen, came to see me, and get your address?  Our Grace and her dear little son Paulding, have been boarding with me,  nearly ever since I came home.  She is trying to make up her mind, where to settle and get a home, since her return from Europe.  For most  reasons, she would rather have a home here in New York; but she cannot afford a house, and she does not like a Flat, on account of the middle sleeping rooms, being dark, and not well ventillated.  Her own handsome Country place, at White Plains, with its big

house of twenty large rooms in it, is too large and expensive for her to live in, so she has decided to allow her Trustee, to try to sell it for her.  She now thinks, from the 1st of May, she will rent a pretty little new, Queen Ann Cottage, at White Plains, and live there; as there is a very fine school for boys there, where she can send Paulding; until he is old enough to go to College.  If she decides upon doing this, she will continue to board with me, until I join Fred, at New Orleans, the first week in January.  Then she would like to rent our Flat, during the time I am away, if you are willing, as Fred and I will be?  She can only afford, where-ever she lives, to pay fifty-dollars a month; this in the Country, will get her a very nice house.  She will keep our Frances, and pay her wages, while I am gone, if we agree to this arrang

Pawlet, Vermont.
July 23rd. 1888
My dear Husband;
Poor Fred is haveing a severe trial with his eyes; since the last letter he wrote to you, just before we started for this place, he has not been able to use is [sic] eyes at all, either to read or write; they are so painful and inflamed.  I was very sick for ten days, before we left New York, with fever and Rheumatic severe pains, all over my body.  As soon as the Doctor got the fever under control, he insisted upon dear Freds takeing me right out of the extreme heat of the City.  I felt I was not able to stand the fatigue of traveling yet, and beged to be allowed to stay home, until I felt stronger.  But our friends were comeing and Fred wished to have the pleasure of traveling with them, up to this Mountain resort.  I was taken very much worse on the steam boat that night, and was very sick during four days and nights, and am now only just able to go down stairs once a day.  I do not gain my strength at all in spite of the braceing, cool, Mountain air;  that blows all the time, through our rooms.  Just as soon as I am able I have asked Fred to take me away from here, as I do not feel, I am deriveing any

benefit from this place.  I want him to go to you and have a nice long visit with you. Fred had so much work to do; altering, cleaning, mending, and re-arrangeing, his forty sets of complete Costumes, and then haveing them all packed up in gum camphor, and tissue paper.  The Costume woman was every day for five weeks, in our house, getting Freds Theatrical wardrobe in perfect order. I did my share of the work, as well as Fred, and we were not ready to come out of town, until just a few days before we did.  I am glad Fred is with friends, he likes here;  as I am too miserable, to be any comfort, or companion, to him.  The air agrees with Fred; he eats and sleeps well, and takes long walks every day. Our friends the Berges, are very refined, cultivated people, and very musical, which just suits Fred, in his tastes.  Fred has taken the kindest and best of care of me, but it is tough, to be sick away from all our home comforts.  I have missed our dear little home, in 125th Street; ever since I left it.  I am very happy and contented there, and most thankful to you, dear Rich, and Fred, my dear boy, for giveing me such a comfortable and pretty home to live in. I hope you are thoroughly well now, and able to enjoy your home and post.  I am glad you are so well fixed with you servants, and hope Laura is

well and will continue to keep so.  When Fred comes to you, I do hope; you will not allow him to ride any  vicious horse, or one that has any tricks, because Fred is plucky enough to ride anything. Do please know all about the horse, before you let him ride him.  It is so easy to be maimed for life by a horse; and if Fred were hurt, all the bright prospects which are opening before him now, for another season, would be ruined.  I will send you by Fred, a clear intelligent, suming up of our entire Rhinelander suit, as it is prepared now to go before the 7 Judges, on the Court of Appeals.  The World Newspaper, has had two very interesting articles, on my case, and without makeing any comments, showed very plainly, the unjust and illegal decision , against all the clear  proofs, in our favor of Referee Hamilton Cole.  I am very thankful to God, and the great Arch Angel Michael, for obtaining for me, such a powerful influence as the World Newspaper, to protect my interests in this case.  I had a most interesting interview, with the gentleman, for an hour and a half, that was sent to hear my story of the case in full.  I saved both the papers to send to you. but by mistake they were taken for something,  When I return, I will go to the Office, and mail them both to you.  I have firm faith, in the ultimate success of our suit; they have not been able to show any right of title to the property; and our title is unbroken.  The Refferee in decideing against us, hoped and believed, I was too poor, to carry our case to the Court of Appeals; and so he, and the Rhinelanders,

[written on advertisement card for Crescent Valley House]
expected to win, by default, as it is called.  They must have used very heavy influence to win Cole over to them; to give a judgement that all the lawyers think not legal. God grant dear Rich, that I may be able to pay you every thousand dollars, that Jordan borrowed of you, to use for Fred.  God bless you dear Rich, for your kindness and forbearance to me, in never haveing reproached me, for this disasterous transaction.  Fred bids me give his love to yourself and Laura and he hopes to be able to tell you in his next letter what day he will come to you.   He has got to find some cheap place to drop me in first; as he wont let me go into the heat of the City.  Good bye, God bless and keep you safe and well, and give you a pleasant summer.  I remain, Your affectionate wife.  Julia R. P. Dodge.

[across top]
I tried to se Mr. Cruikshank in regard to the annoyance Aunt Kates husband has tried to give you.  He has tried to worry me too but he cannot do more than what he has.  You are all clear and protected by law - Mr. Cruikshank told me this a long time ago, because he had all the receipts, that the legacies were paid to the persons designated   Mine & Freds; Kate only had a life interest. With much love to your self, and praying God to bless you in health and prosperity. and my love to Laura.  I remain your grateful wife. Julia. 
New York City, 
Sunday Nov 27th 1887
My Dear Husband;  I cannot express to you in words, the deep debt of gratitude I owe to you, for your prompt and generous assistance, in this sudden and unprepared cricis, of our case.  After admitting all our proofs found in the City Records, and all those other proofs, of the sale of the property we claim; by Trinity Church Corporation, to our Uncle William Rhinelander, and the record of the Trusteeship on file, proveing the validity of the papers I hold, which I found.  The Refferee Mr. Hamilton Cole, gives an illegal decision, without any proofs to sustain his decision; that he believes, the property belonged to Frederick Rhinelander our great GrandFather; were

this true; which thank God, it is not; we could not inherit the property we do.  As our inheritance by law, comes through, my dear Grandmother's brother, and not by or through her Father, who we all know, left the large bulk of his great Estate, to his son, and his own brother, after leaveing my Grandmother Maria Rhinelander, his only daughter, eight hundred thousand dollars of, valuable real Estate.  Under oath, and after four months hard fight, they cannot show any title in any shape, to the property we have, the clear title to, and so clearly proved by our lawyers.  There is but one conclusion to be drawn, and that is, they must have heavily influenced the Refferee, against all legal proof; which we have shown to our lawful rights, by inheritance, to the property in question, for him to be willing to give to the Supreme Court, such a decision.  The Rhinelanders hoped and trusted, that I was too

to poor to stand the expense, of an Appeal to the Court of Appeals.  Mr. Bussey took it for granted, that Mr. Greenfield, the present Trustee of Uncle Philip Pauldings Estate, would furnish the full amount.  Which Mr. Greenfield very justly refused to do .  As Gracies property through Judge Mills, breach of Trust, has dwindled away, to only a very small income for herself and Paulie.  Mr. Bussey up to the last moment, thought he could induce Mr. Greenfield to consent; this was Wednesday.  I knew nothing of the true state of affairs, until Wednesday night, at ten o'clock; and Thanksgiveing Day, between, a Holiday to give us all the less time.  I am greatly surprised, that Mr. Bussey should have taken it so for granted, that Gracie would furnish all the money. She had not the money to put up suddenly.  So after all his hard work, on the case for the past three years, he came very near letting the whole case, go by default.  As the lawyers, on the other side, I would not

grant us an extension.  But for your timely and most kind assistance, just at this cricis, we would have lost our fortune, beyond a doubt.  I have never lost hope, in our great case, being finally decided in our lawful right to the property.  It has ben supernaturally guided and protected, all through for us and will be until the end, when the great Arch Angel Michael, and my own dear Angel Guardian, will win for us.  Every proof we have found has been found in a most marvelous manner; the way in which everything through the old letters, and papers I found, has been developed to prove our rights, is most curious and interesting, and I know and believe, is in direct answer, to my prayers, devotion, and faith in , Almighty God and my own dear Angel Guardian.  For me to doubt the final decision in our favor; would be most disloyal, and a great want of faith, to God and my Angel Guardian, Mr. Greenfield will make out the legal paper you are to sign, as my security and I am to send it to you, to be executed, before a Notary Public, and then it at once return to him, to

(5)
place on file, in the record Office, in this City.  Gracie is deeply grateful to you, for what you have done for me, for with out this promise from you; our suit at this most critical time, would have had to be abandoned;  with success just within our reach.  Gracie bids me tell you she does not require any legal paper to bind you;  for as a gentleman and an Officer, your word is sufficient.  But her Trustee Mr. Greenfield says, he wishes you to sign the paper, I am to send you, when I receive it.  I had to have a Bonds Man also, and Mr. J. M. Hill, was sworn in for me.  I am so greatful to him, for doing this for Fred and me.  I am very sorry to find, from your recent letter, that your cook is to leave you, and that the cooking, even for a short time, should devolve upon Laura, who has not the strength to stand it.  You know, she must get over heated, constantly in cooking; then going into cooler rooms, she must get a check of persper

ation, at least twice, each day; one of the very worst things, that can happen to her.  So my advice is, get a cook at once, Some one from Watertown, or vicinity, who will not get lonesome in the Country, or have her head turned by the soldiers.  In every letter, I give dear Fred, my advice, to keep up and bear with Miss Mathers insulting treatment, until the close of his present season.  I know well, how hard it is, for him to bear, when she does all she can to spoil his scenes, and get bad press notices for him.  On my own responsibility, and from my Mothers love and anxiety, for his future success, in his profession, I went to Mr. Hill; as I told him, without Freds knowledge; and made a plain statement of facts, and appealed to him, as Fred's manager not to allow Miss Mather or her young inexperienced husband to injure our Son, with the Press.  I told Mr. Hill, that as a Star, Miss Mather had no right to try to hurt Freds Artistic work, with the Press.  That he knew, the good

reputation Fred had made, as a very promising and talented young Tragic Actor, working hard for the past eight years.  I said I came to you first for justice and reperation in this matter; as I know if you choose you can protect, my Sons work as an Actor, from being injured by her jealousy. He said "Mrs. Dodge, you are right, in the stand you have taken in this matter; Fred deserves, from his good work, for the past five years under my management, to be well taken care of, and he shall.  He Mr. Hill, then wrote, a strong letter to Mr. Prescott, the Advance Agent, who has the handling of the Press, before the Star plays "In every way protect and further Mr. Pauldings interests, for the remainder of this season". This is my wish.  J. M. Hill. "  I know, that if Mr. Hills plans for next season, work as he is now planning for, Fred will be taken from Miss Mather, and be brought out, in a fine Shakespearian production, to run all winter, at the Union Square Theatre, in the

principal male role.  This would be superb for our dear boy, and his good and most artistic work, all through the Country, under Mr. Hills management, and his excellent Moral Character, has gained for him this fine opening with Mr. Hill, for next season.  I am quoting Mr. Hills own words about Fred . What I have just mentioned to you; is a secret yet.  Mr. Hill does not wish the Press, to get hold of what he intends to do or Mather; who would then certainly, make Freds acting with her unendurable longer.  Mr. Hill told me I could write this to Fred, to encourage him for the remainder of the season; but that he trusted to his honor and mine, not to speak of his intentions and plans further.  I can see dawning, what Mr. Hill wishes to make of his Union Square Theatre.  The Lyceum for all Legitimate Drama, with Fred, in all the leading roles, as the Stock Star, and no more traveling on the road, except in the Spring, an engagement in Chicago and Boston.  With Mr. Hills experience and Capital, I am sure he will make his Theatre here pay well.

Ed did not know Gen'l Alexander, so I gave him your P.S. & told him to enclose the same to him, believing that it would help him to have a friend so high in Office, ( & by the bye I believe that is why you wrote as you did)  so Ed enclosed your P.S. with a polite note from himself, & yesterday received the enclosed letter, which I am sure you will appreciate.  There is so much whole heartedness about it; that it did
[across top]
excuse this hasty note, & be sure & let me know when Fred will come South.  Ed sends love & says the hunting here is good, & if you come you will have a warm welcome.  With love I remain your affection sister Annie Glenn
Excuse the paper as I am out, & must use Ed's.

me good to feel there was some one who could remember past kindness & whose soul was not entirely immersed in the one idea of gaining money.  Ed's being from a different State has been the cause of a good deal of jealousy, & others less deserving have been put over his head;  but in spite of this he is steadily rising, & is eventually sure of success.
The only trouble is that it is hard to live in this climate on $75 per month, as the Doctor's bills alone almost come up to that  Ed was very much gratified to find that no one in the Office was able to do his work & since his return he has had no end to the little acts of kindness and attention shown him, altho sick for three weeks he will draw his regular pay & hopes soon to have it increased, as every one now acknowledges his ability.  You have no doubt heard of, & been grieved to hear of the sudden death of Judge Settle.  I enclose a notice of it from the Greensboro Workman.  There is no doubt now that Col [unclear] will have to go out of office, as he has made himself so unpopular -- Please

[across top]
meals when I travel with Fred, and I shall do the same while I am visiting you & I do not wish or mean, to give trouble in your most comfortable and well appointed home.  My Poll  died last year, so you will not be annoyed by her screaming or whistling . I would not get another, on account of Freds neuralgia in his heart.  Good bye, dear Rich. Dec. 20th 1888
My dear Husband;
I  was very glad to receive, your kind, welcome, letter,  of last Sunday.  What a very narrow escape from death, [Lutwright?] had, give him my kind regards and congratulations, that he was saved.  He was so kind and attentive, to dear good Joe, during his severe illness, that I shall always like [Lutwright?], for it, and believe, he will make Laura, a good husband, as she well deserves;  I sent to you, this morning, and did not pay express charges, on the box as they are more likely to deliver promptly when they are not paid. A gallon, of what I am told, and believe to be, very fine

old, Rye Whiskey, for your +mas gift from me, and hope you will relish it very much.  Packed in the box with the demijon of Whiskey, is a small bottle, of a liniment, which I want to have you try, when your Rheumatism troubles you; it is very powerful, and you must only bathe, very gently with it, for not more than ten or fifteen minutes, at a time, and not bandage the limb after useing it.  Before rubing with this liniment, the affected part, must be well soaked for ten minutes, in water, as hot, as you can bear it.  I know of several severe cases of Rheumatism, that it has given prompt relief to; it is the discovery of a young Chemist, whom we all know well.  It is to be used, three times a day, and on retireing for the night.  I shall send tomorrow by mail, to Laura, a little +mas gift, of a

real Duchess lace collar; it is the fashionable lace, most worn, by all the ladies, tell Laura for the past few months.  Give Laura my love, and tell her, I hope she will keep well, and have a pleasant winter.  I am all ready, and was to have started this evening, to join our dear Son, at Atlanta, to rush through the South with him.  Tuesday afternoon, I received this telegram; "Do not join me, will be home in two weeks".  Last night, came a long letter, from Fred, telling me, Mr. Hill would call the Company in because the public do not like the play.   Fred gets every where, high praise, plenty of applause, every night, and fine, news paper notices, for his rendering of his part; but the play is condemned, for being badly constructed, improbable, immoral, and much too talky, when Fred is off the scene.  I am not surprised, that Mr. Hill will bring it in, for I know, he has lost over,

six thousand dollars, since it went on the road; and here, in New York, it drew finely , so that Mr. Hill, tried hard, to buy off other attractions, to keep Fred on in it, for a long run.  I suppose Fred, and all the company , will be out of engagements now, until the Spring season opens, in March, with new plays.  I wish so much, dear Rich, you would let Fred and I come to visit you, for the next two months; we would both like so much, to see you, and I know, the entire rest and change of life, and scene, would be of great benefit, to our dear Son, for you know from what I have written you, in one of my former letters, how much the dear boy requires, mental and physical refreshment.  You need not be afraid, dear Rich, that I will disarrange your household, by my bad habits, or inconvenience your cook; I am on time for my

My own darling

  Your dear letter reached me today. I've been so worried about you. If you do not improve, I insist upon your seeing the Doctor. I can only write a few lines now -- my pet, as I must get to rehearsal. I wish you a happy birthday and many of them with me. Get your dress at once. Everything is fine here and I feel that I am now established here firmly unless something unforeseen occurs to which God prevent! -- We go away for a week - during the week of Oct 24. returning 30th I want you to be

prepared to leave New York on the evening of Sunday Oct 30th or Monday 31. - so as to arrive here on Nov 1st Tuesday or Wednesday at least. Your room is engaged from the first of November. [two unclear words} you out by the West Shore Road and will have your ticket waiting for you and paid for in unclear all you'll have to do is is call for it and present your letter which I will send you.  Get your berth then.   I'll send all money for the presents.  [two unclear words] etc in time. [unclear] my costume trunks.  I need [unclear]  my costumes if the trunks are not [unclear] have them [unclear]  crated and sent fast [unclear].   Whatever you and [?Berger?] think best. Remember your room is engaged from Nov 1st so get ready and

[stamp of The Aberdeen Milwaukee]
dont delay in coming.   God bless you always.  I am well [unclear].  Our rooms are simply beautiful and I've made [unclear] friends.   Our rooms are next each other and each is larger than the big one you had at last Smythes so bring some lamps and little pretty things you are now using as God willing, we'll be here for the next six or eight [unclear] except during my little tour in [?January?]  Love and kisses Ever your devoted boy Fritz

130 E [?] St.
My own darling.
It is fearfully warm tonight and I am feeling very depressed and blue.  Poor Charlie Paulding, died last night and they are bringing the body home to bury him beside his father.  My heart bleeds for [?] to whom "Chub" was more than Father.  Nothing after [?...'s?] loss could have beset him so, except possibly the passing of Elise.  and to make it doubly hard - Entre nous, Margaret is such a

helpless, hopeless specimen of woman - that I imagine the care of the two children, Lov and the six months baby, named for [?Keike?] will devolve upon [?Keike?] and the two girls, especially if Margaret remarries as I presume being young and handsome she will, in time.  I cannot find words to condole with [Keike?] and yet he is so simply sensitive, that one has to be extra careful, lest one says the slightest word, too much.  I shall, of course, go up to the funeral and receive at the funeral mass.  I presume they will pile in here by Monday and I will get a

rooms somewhere near, for the remainder of my stay.  I expect to sign my contract to-morrow, and begin rehearsals on Monday,  The moment the contract is signed, I will tell you all about it, but I cannot bear to disappoint you and until it is positive, I don't want to tell you.  I was to sign on Tuesday, but the contracts were not ready and I was told to come in to-morrow.  I was also to read my play to one of the greatest managers in the Country on Tuesday Evening last, but something else engaged his time and he has set tomorrow - Thursday

Evening at nine thirty, to hear it, but it seems too good to be true!  Meantime, I am dictating it to the typewriters and it certainly does stand the test of repetition. I am very happy over the effect.  Mr. Edwards says he has no fear for its future and, of course, after that I need not worry for any of my plays.  If I sign tomorrow, we open Sept 25th and just after that are in Chicago I want you to join me when I leave there, and travel East with me to New York. what a bad season it is, when even Freddie Peters, is not yet engaged.

Tell them I want them to know the new play and will probably send a copy on just for them to read.  I hope to get up to [?Eillies?] the first of the week.  She is wretched.  Grace is very well.  Paul doing splendidly.  I see [?Loriel?] frequently

Feb 3rd 1904
My own darling

   I've no news to write about. Things go along here comfortably. Included some notices of next; or rather this week's bill - a lurid melo-drama which I think is very "awful" from a literary point of view; but "What's the odds" if it pleases the public and it does. I do not play next week and only a small part the week after and I've really plenty of time for rest between the hills?. I don't want to boast but I really am very well. I'm sleeping splendidly - my body feels strong - my spirits are excellent and I don't have those fits of restless depression I used to undergo. I haven't had but one cold since I came here. The weather now is perfect; soft and balmy - with that "nip" enough in the air to make one feel good. My play will very shortly be

done at the Castle Square in Boston.  I've sent them music - scene plots - and everything.  Jack [?Sainpolis?] is to do the Priest, am I not fortunate?   I have heard nothing more regarding the Chicago production, but the transcript and parts reached there O.K.  so my agent informs me.  I am so hoping that I may be able to bring you down here in April, I want you to meet the people who have been so kind to me, and to Escape the awful weather north.  I had a lovely letter from Phil [?Grace?] to-day. Dear [?Lettie Akin?] has been very ill again, but is better now.  I love you!  God bless and keep you, my own beloved!  Send the bill for last month's board.  Love and kisses - always your devoted son, Fritz

My own dear Mother.
There is so much to tell  you that I scarcely know where to begin.  As you seem to be inclined to indulge your old and bad habit of worrying, let me first set your mind at rest regarding the future.  There is absolutely nothing for you to worry over.  Regarding my business affairs, and the conduct of them, be assured that I am satisfied in nearly every particular as to method and result - at all times we cannot hope for "nothing but sunshine" and allmighty God has been so good to me and bestowed

The effect of it has been [?], but not permanently, by Mr Murphy's peculiar coarsening and slowing of the Character, his wife inability or disinclination to play the heroine along the lines of my conception and the drunken life of the star; which causes him not only to [?] peculiar performances, but to close his season six weeks ahead of time.  These facts cannot be known to the general public and would do us good if they were; for the public has no use for these kind of disagreements.  Well, we have taken the play away from him.  We can place it in stock at good money, but one season in stock at good money; or at the outside two, kills the play forever, for a star and [?] and five percent" royalties - and altho it is an eccentric role and play Mr. Edwards has supreme faith in its future; and will not allow it to go in stock until all its possibilities as a money maker have been utilized.   He says he will keep it idle until my new play is a great hit - and then "Two Men" will go with a [?] rather than take stock engagements now which while they may bring in eighteen hundred dollars this season, will bring in twenty five hundred two years from now; with an intermediary season with some star of three thousand more. This is hard common sense and I mean to abide absolutely by his wish.  He is unquestionably the greatest play broker in America and has enormous influence and [?] to be as wax in his hands for he has supreme faith in my future and has done splendidly for me so far.  So I do not Count on a dollar from "Two [?] and a fire"

So many blessings upon you and me that I should be an ingrate to cry out, because I wasn't given every thing I wished for.  Things regarding the plays have not been as I could wish, or had hoped for, but it is only temporary and while I am sorry it is so, I certainly am in a much better position than even a year ago; as I have fewer debts, and my assets in the way of plays, are not [?retire?].  You know as I told you in Chicago that my "Notre Dame" is in the hands of a fiend, I do not doubt that I am sure they are cheating me, and cannot yet prove it, all I can do is watch closely and in a quiet way try to push the play - Which I am still doing.   The Murphy play is very valuable property

This Company [?] on the Country.  I expect "Trooper Billie" to [?] on a round of the stocks in about two months, as Mr Edwards or rather his firm is making an arrangement with me to provide handsome printing for the play, without which it is impossible to get good stock time for any new play.  I am to re-write the first act, which did not please me.  When I saw it acted, and as soon as the printing is ready "Trooper Billie" will go forth.  As to the new play, it has made a sensation and Mr Edwards told Fred Peters, who told me with tears in his eyes, that it was the best Comedy he had read in ten years and he regarded me as the coming dramatist of the Country.  I have an appointment made by Mr Edwards to read it aloud

sign contracts on Friday.  I am to sign them on Tuesday, God willing.   The firm is a New York one and has been after me two weeks.  I've refused it twice, on account of Salary, but they finally came to my terms; it is a good part, not great, a splendid New York production opening on October 15 - and if it goes on tour later, only the largest cities.  The performances are only Eight per week not a long role; (Comedy.) no study and nothing to do with the stage management.  I have told no one and I don't intend to say another word about it, until the Contracts are signed.  If I take it, we will open in Chicago in September, and I shall want you all packed with things shipped to New York; then, personally you can join me and travel back to N.Y. with me.  I think I will live in White Plains with you for the [?].  if we can do well there this is all the news of business and please keep it to yourself until I am sure of it.  Charlie Paulding is - I fear, dying.  Kirke and Hattie are with him in the Adirondacks, where his wife and children and nurses are with him.  They are afraid to Summer in [?] for fear it will State his [?] and altho I'm hopeing against hope; I should not be surprised to receive a letter or wire from Kirke at any moment.  I return on Monday to town, but return next week to remain until rehearsals begin, that is if I sign, as I expect to do.  Kittie is still a martyr, a saint also [?] a lesson in beautiful Christian patience and fortitude.  I am always happy

on Tuesday night next to the greatest manager and producer in America. I dare not tell you his name yet, because -, frankly it seems to me to be too good to be true - and I do not want your hopes dashed down too far in case he fails to keep the appointment, but I saw his letter making it and saying he would let me read it. Which Mr Edwards says is an unheard of Concession on his part. In any case, his Edwards says he will have no trouble in placing the new play and is most anxious - for me, after a little rest to begin a new play for one of our big stars who is interested. Under these conditions - I practically settled for next season - the day I came up here -, but I would not

been, it has an atmosphere, a peace, purity and freedom from the ....ly dusty? influence of the world at large that is very grateful to my senses.   Now that the strain of writing the play is removed and it is an accomplished fact and a successful one, the relaxation is really powerful and I am simply  giving my self up to resting in "unclear".   I am wonderfully well, but just tired out and a few days of this beautiful quiet and pure air will soon put me right again.  I had such a sweet but sad experience last Sunday morning; when I went to early mass up in Harlem - at our old St Joseph's Church.  I had gone to the new and magnificent Turkish Bath built almost opposite our old flat in 125th St and getting

give you more details until I am positive of them.  I am sorry I cant do anything for Anita Anderson.  I shall not be director and have nothing to do with the stage.  All I can do is introduce her to agents.  The unclear Company and Mr Jones's have been filled for weeks.  I introduced Anita to our [two unclear words] if she had written me earlier or during the vacation I might have done something for her, as he was pleased with her appearance, but I had my play to think of and forgot all about her, as she did not write me about, as I told her to in Chicago.  I did place one of my boys with Mr Mantell, but the Company is full as regards everybody, [two unclear words] be and Mr James open in two weeks and are rehearsing.  Give my love to Phil Grace.  I am so thankful you are well and happy.  You can begin to pack up very soon.  Love to the Quinns.  Grace is very well.  Haven't heard from Jule Parrott in answer to mine.  Grace thinks Mary expects another baby, which would account for Jule's silence, but they are all so queer, "You never can tell."  God bless and keep you, dearest.  I said the beads for you to-day and remember you at Mass.  Kittie sends her love.  Love and kisses - Always Your devoted son,  Fritz
August 20th, 1905

up at half past five, went to six o'clock mass.                                                                                        Nashville, Tenn. Feb. 5th 1904

My own darling
Did a set of new books -- "Holmes Lectures" come for me since I left home? I ordered them on subscription last September - to be sent January 10 - and I have received a notification from the Battle Creek - Michigan Pub Co -, that they delivered them. Of course - I don't want them now, as the books are to be packed away, and shall write them at once, asking them to take them back -- And I shall explain the situation to George Des Forges and ask him to take back the Byron's . The set is in perfect condition and I shall tell him to look at it first & be sure -, if he does not wish to do this -, then I can only pay

him little by little - as I do the others. There were Ten Volumes of "The Drama" when I left, with more to come. I am now paying that bill - The Scribners and unclear; So they will not trouble you; Hereafter they will send to me. I sent you unclear bill -, Please send me Slater's bill' I do not know the amount; but the bill itself - fos? the amount now due. I will pay up? Laske's immediately and then, as soon as possible -- something on each pupil's debt till all are paid. I save this money for debts off my hotel bill and yours - that is why - the giving up of the two rooms and saving on your money and mine for the next few months is so necessary - as I have often explained to you. God bless and keep you -, I love you - always Your loving --

                      Fritz

Good Notice.
Feb. 3rd 1904 ---
Mrs. Julia P. Dodge,
Hotel Aberdeen,
Milwaukee, Wis.

4/23/05

My dear Fred, --

    Congratulations my dear boy! The papers have treated you very kindly & the show as a whole simply great.
    I just got in and am hustling around so hard I cannot find time to get over to see you but I do not want you to forget our luncheon date for tomorrow noon. I shall show up at the theatre about twelve and I hope that is satisfactory.
    It did me a great deal of good to see you and I cannot tell you how I appreciate your cheerful words to me and your aid & sympathy.
    Until tomorrow (Tuesday) at noon at the stage door - adios -
                 Sincerely
                      Duane
